name: aac
title: AAC audio file format
description: Advanced Audio Coding format, designed to be the successor format to MP3, with generally better sound quality.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to only supporting AAC in an MP4 container and only when the operating system already has the codecs installed.

name: abortcontroller
title: AbortController & AbortSignal
description: Controller object that allows you to abort one or more DOM requests made with the Fetch API.

notes_by_num.1: Safari has window.AbortController defined in the DOM but it's just a stub, it does not abort requests at all. The same issue also affects Chrome on IOS and Firefox on IOS because they use the same WebKit rendering engine as Safari.

name: accelerometer
title: Accelerometer
description: Defines `Accelerometer`, `LinearAccelerationSensor` and `GravitySensor` interfaces for obtaining information about acceleration applied to the X, Y and Z axis of a device that hosts the sensor.

notes_by_num.1: Available by enabling the "Generic Sensor" experimental flag in `about:flags`

name: addeventlistener
title: EventTarget.addEventListener()
description: The modern standard API for adding DOM event handlers. Introduced in the DOM Level 2 Events spec. Also implies support for `removeEventListener`, the [capture phase](https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-event-capturing_phase) of DOM event dispatch, as well as the `stopPropagation()` and `preventDefault()` event methods.

notes_by_num.1: IE<=8 instead only supports the [proprietary `.attachEvent()` method](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener). It also does not support the [capture phase](https://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-3-Events/#event-flow) of DOM event dispatch; it only supports event bubbling.
notes_by_num.2: The `useCapture` parameter is non-optional and must be provided. Future versions made it optional, with a default value of `false`.

name: ambient-light
title: Ambient Light Sensor
description: Defines a concrete sensor interface to monitor the ambient light level or illuminance of the deviceâ€™s environment.

notes_by_num.1: Implements an [outdated version of the spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/2015/WD-ambient-light-20150903/).
notes_by_num.2: Available by enabling the "Generic Sensor Extra Classes" experimental flag in `about:flags`

name: apng
title: Animated PNG (APNG)
description: Like animated GIFs, but allowing 24-bit colors and alpha transparency

name: array-find
title: Array.prototype.find
description: The `find()` method returns the value of the first item in the array based on the result of the provided testing function.

name: array-find-index
title: Array.prototype.findIndex
description: The `findIndex()` method returns the index of the first element in the array that satisfies the provided testing function.

name: array-flat
title: flat & flatMap array methods
description: Methods to flatten any sub-arrays found in an array by concatenating their elements.

name: array-includes
title: Array.prototype.includes
description: Determines whether or not an array includes the given value, returning a boolean value (unlike `indexOf`).

name: arrow-functions
title: Arrow functions
description: Function shorthand using `=>` syntax and lexical `this` binding.

name: asmjs
title: asm.js
description: An extraordinarily optimizable, low-level subset of JavaScript, intended to be a compile target from languages like C++.

notes_by_num.1: Chrome does not support Ahead-Of-Time compilation but performance doubled in Chrome 28: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asm.js#Implementations
notes_by_num.2: Supported in MS Edge under the "Enable experimental JavaScript features" flag.

name: async-functions
title: Async functions
description: Async functions make it possible to treat functions returning Promise objects as if they were synchronous.

notes_by_num.1: Since build 14342 - disabled by default; can be enabled through about:flags
notes_by_num.2: Async functions are present in Firefox Nightly since 31th October 2016.
notes_by_num.3: Async arrow functions are [unsupported](https://github.com/kangax/compat-table/pull/1420).

name: atob-btoa
title: Base64 encoding and decoding
description: Utility functions for of encoding and decoding strings to and from base 64: window.atob() and window.btoa().

name: audio
title: Audio element
description: Method of playing sound on webpages (without requiring a plug-in). Includes support for the following media properties: `currentSrc`, `currentTime`, `paused`, `playbackRate`, `buffered`, `duration`, `played`, `seekable`, `ended`, `autoplay`, `loop`, `controls`, `volume` & `muted`

notes_by_num.1: Old Firefox versions were missing support for some properties: `loop` was added in v11, `played` in v15, `playbackRate` in v20.

name: audio-api
title: Web Audio API
description: High-level JavaScript API for processing and synthesizing audio

name: audiotracks
title: Audio Tracks
description: Method of specifying and selecting between multiple audio tracks. Useful for providing audio descriptions, director's commentary, additional languages, alternative takes, etc.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox by enabling "media.track.enabled" in about:config
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Chrome and Opera by enabling "enable-experimental-web-platform-features" in chrome:flags

name: autofocus
title: Autofocus attribute
description: Allows a form field to be immediately focused on page load.

name: auxclick
title: Auxclick
description: The click event for non-primary buttons of input devices

notes_by_num.1: As a compatibility measure, Firefox continues to fire the click event for document and window level event handlers.

name: av1
title: AV1 video format
description: AV1 (AOMedia Video 1) is a royalty-free video format by the Alliance for Open Media, meant to succeed its predecessor VP9 and compete with the HEVC/H.265 format.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Edge 18 by installing the AV1 Video Extension from the Microsoft Store
notes_by_num.2: Firefox 65 only supported Windows 64-bit users by default
notes_by_num.3: Firefox 66 only supported Windows and macOS users by default
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled in older Firefox versions via the `media.av1.enabled` flag in `about:config`

name: avif
title: AVIF image format
description: A modern image format based on the AV1 video format. AVIF generally has better compression than [WebP](#feat=webp), JPEG, PNG and GIF and is designed to supersede them.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox via the `image.avif.enabled` flag in `about:config`

name: background-attachment
title: CSS background-attachment
description: Method of defining how a background image is attached to a scrollable element. Values include `scroll` (default), `fixed` and `local`.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to supporting `fixed` but not `local`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to supporting `local` but not `fixed`
notes_by_num.3: Only supports `local` when `-webkit-overflow-scrolling: touch` is _not_ used
notes_by_num.4: Does not support `fixed`, and due [to a bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=627037) only supports `local` if a `border-radius` is set on the element.

name: background-img-opts
title: CSS3 Background-image options
description: New properties to affect background images, including background-clip, background-origin and background-size

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Opera Mini refers to not supporting background sizing or background attachments. However Opera Mini 7.5 supports background sizing (including cover and contain values).
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari 6 refers to not supporting background sizing offset from edges syntax.
notes_by_num.3: Does not support `background-size` values in the `background` shorthand

name: background-position-x-y
title: background-position-x & background-position-y
description: CSS longhand properties to define x or y positions separately.

name: background-repeat-round-space
title: CSS background-repeat round and space
description: Allows CSS background images to be repeated without clipping.

notes_by_num.1: IE9 does not appear to render "background-repeat: round" correctly.

name: background-sync
title: Background Sync API
description: Provides one-off and periodic synchronization for Service Workers with an onsync event.

name: battery-status
title: Battery Status API
description: Method to provide information about the battery status of the hosting device.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to support for the older specification's `navigator.battery` rather than `navigator.getBattery()` to access the `BatteryManager`.

name: beacon
title: Beacon API
description: Allows data to be sent asynchronously to a server with `navigator.sendBeacon`, even after a page was closed. Useful for posting analytics data the moment a user was finished using the page.

name: beforeafterprint
title: Printing Events
description: Window fires `beforeprint` and `afterprint` events so the printed document can be annotated.

name: bigint
title: BigInt
description: Arbitrary-precision integers in JavaScript.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled by setting `javascript.options.bigint` to "True" in `about:config`

name: blobbuilder
title: Blob constructing
description: Construct Blobs (binary large objects) either using the BlobBuilder API (deprecated) or the Blob constructor.

name: bloburls
title: Blob URLs
description: Method of creating URL handles to the specified File or Blob object.

notes_by_num.1: Created blob url can't be used as object or iframe src

name: border-image
title: CSS3 Border images
description: Method of using images for borders

notes_by_num.1: Has a bug where `border-image` incorrectly overrides `border-style`. See [test case](https://codepen.io/Savago/pen/yYrgyK), [WebKit bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=99922), [discussion](https://github.com/whatwg/compat/issues/17)
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting `border-image-repeat: space`
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to supporting the shorthand syntax, but not the individual properties (`border-image-source`, `border-image-slice`, etc).
notes_by_num.4: Partial support refers to not supporting `border-image-repeat: round`

name: border-radius
title: CSS3 Border-radius (rounded corners)
description: Method of making the border corners round. Covers support for the shorthand `border-radius` as well as the long-hand properties (e.g. `border-top-left-radius`)

notes_by_num.1: Safari 6.1 and earlier did not apply `border-radius` correctly to image borders: https://stackoverflow.com/q/17202128
notes_by_num.2: Dotted and dashed rounded border corners are rendered as solid in Firefox. [see bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=382721)

name: broadcastchannel
title: BroadcastChannel
description: BroadcastChannel allows scripts from the same origin but other browsing contexts (windows, workers) to send each other messages.

name: brotli
title: Brotli Accept-Encoding/Content-Encoding
description: More effective lossless compression algorithm than gzip and deflate.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Chrome and Opera behind the 'Brotli Content-Encoding' flag
notes_by_num.2: Enabled since 27 May 2016
notes_by_num.3: Support starting with macOS 10.13 High Sierra

name: calc
title: calc() as CSS unit value
description: Method of allowing calculated values for length units, i.e. `width: calc(100% - 3em)`

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Android Browser 4.4 refers to the browser lacking the ability to multiply and divide values.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE9 refers to the browser crashing when used as a `background-position` value.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in IE10/IE11 refers to calc not working properly with various use cases mentioned in known issues

name: canvas
title: Canvas (basic support)
description: Method of generating fast, dynamic graphics using JavaScript.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `toDataURL()`
notes_by_num.2: Opera Mini supports the canvas element, but is unable to play animations or run other more complex applications.

name: canvas-blending
title: Canvas blend modes
description: Method of defining the effect resulting from overlaying two layers on a Canvas element.

name: canvas-text
title: Text API for Canvas
description: Method of displaying text on Canvas elements

name: ch-unit
title: ch (character) unit
description: Unit representing the width of the character "0" in the current font, of particular use in combination with monospace fonts.

notes_by_num.1: IE supports the `ch` unit, but unlike other browsers its width is that specifically of the "0" glyph, not its surrounding space. As a result, 3ch for example is shorter than the width of the string "000" in IE.

name: chacha20-poly1305
title: ChaCha20-Poly1305 cipher suites for TLS
description: A set of cipher suites used in Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol, using ChaCha20 for symmetric encryption and Poly1305 for authentication.

notes_by_num.1: Old versions of Chrome use non-standard code points for ChaCha20-Poly1305 cipher suites.

name: channel-messaging
title: Channel messaging
description: Method for having two-way communication between browsing contexts (using MessageChannel)

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox behind the `dom.messageChannel.enabled` flag. Reported to not work in web workers before version 41.

name: childnode-remove
title: ChildNode.remove()
description: DOM node method to remove the node itself from the document.

name: classlist
title: classList (DOMTokenList)
description: Method of easily manipulating classes on elements, using the DOMTokenList object.

notes_by_num.1: Does not have support for `classList` on SVG or MathML elements.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support the second parameter for the `toggle` method
notes_by_num.3: Does not support multiple parameters for the `add()` & `remove()` methods
notes_by_num.4: Does not support assign to `classList` or the `replace()` method

name: client-hints-dpr-width-viewport
title: Client Hints: DPR, Width, Viewport-Width
description: DPR, Width, and Viewport-Width hints enable proactive content negotiation between client and server, enabling automated delivery of optimized assets - e.g. auto-negotiating image DPR resolution.

name: clipboard
title: Synchronous Clipboard API
description: API to provide copy, cut and paste events as well as provide access to the OS clipboard.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports `Text` and `URL` data types and uses [a non-standard method](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/ms535220%28v=vs.85%29.aspx) of interacting with the clipboard.
notes_by_num.2: Only fires `copy` event on a valid selection and only `cut` and `paste` in focused editable fields.
notes_by_num.3: Only supports OS clipboard reading/writing via shortcut keys, not through `document.execCommand()`.
notes_by_num.4: Only supports `paste` event (on focused editable field).
notes_by_num.5: Does not support the `ClipboardEvent` constructor
notes_by_num.6: Supports `cut` & `copy` events without a focused editable field, but not `paste` (presumably for security reasons)
notes_by_num.7: Supports `cut` & `copy` events without a focused editable field, but does not fire `paste` with `document.execCommand('paste')`

name: comparedocumentposition
title: Node.compareDocumentPosition()
description: Compares the relative position of two nodes to each other in the DOM tree.

notes_by_num.1: The spec requires that comparisons of nodes in different documents, and comparisons where at least one node is not in any document, must arbitrarily (but consistently) set either the `DOCUMENT_POSITION_PRECEDING` or `DOCUMENT_POSITION_FOLLOWING` bit in the result. These browser versions don't set either bit in some such cases.
notes_by_num.2: Sets neither the `DOCUMENT_POSITION_DISCONNECTED` bit nor the `DOCUMENT_POSITION_IMPLEMENTATION_SPECIFIC` bit in some cases when comparing nodes in different documents or when comparing a node which is not in any document.

name: console-basic
title: Basic console logging functions
description: Method of outputting data to the browser's console, intended for development purposes.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports console functions when developer tools are open, otherwise the `console` object is undefined and any calls will throw errors.
notes_by_num.2: Allows `console` functions to be used without throwing errors, but does not appear to output the data anywhere.
notes_by_num.3: Log output on iOS 6+ Safari can only be seen by connecting to a Mac and using the [Safari debugger](https://developer.apple.com/safari/tools/).
notes_by_num.4: Log output on older Android browsers can be retrieved via Android's `logcat` command or using Chrome Developer Tools in Android 4.4+/Chrome for Android [see details](https://developer.android.com/guide/webapps/debugging.html)
notes_by_num.5: Log output on Firefox for Android can be [accessed using WebIDE](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Tools/Remote_Debugging/Debugging_Firefox_for_Android_with_WebIDE)
notes_by_num.6: See [this article](https://dev.opera.com/articles/opera-mini-and-javascript/) for details on how to see console logging in Opera Mini

name: console-time
title: console.time and console.timeEnd
description: Functions for measuring performance

name: const
title: const
description: Declares a constant with block level scope

notes_by_num.1: const is recognized, but treated like var (no block scope, can be overwritten)
notes_by_num.2: const does not have block scope
notes_by_num.3: Only recognized when NOT in strict mode
notes_by_num.4: Supported correctly in strict mode, otherwise supported without block scope
notes_by_num.5: Not supported in for-in and for-of loops

name: constraint-validation
title: Constraint Validation API
description: API for better control over form field validation. Includes support for `checkValidity()`, `setCustomValidity()`, `reportValidity()` and validation states.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `reportValidity`
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `validity.tooShort`. See also [support for `minlength`.](https://caniuse.com/#feat=input-minlength)
notes_by_num.3: Does not support `validity.badInput`

name: contenteditable
title: contenteditable attribute (basic support)
description: Method of making any HTML element editable.

name: contentsecuritypolicy
title: Content Security Policy 1.0
description: Mitigate cross-site scripting attacks by only allowing certain sources of script, style, and other resources.

notes_by_num.1: Supported through the `X-Content-Security-Policy` header
notes_by_num.2: Supported through the `X-WebKit-CSP` header

name: contentsecuritypolicy2
title: Content Security Policy Level 2
description: Mitigate cross-site scripting attacks by only allowing certain sources of script, style, and other resources. CSP 2 adds hash-source, nonce-source, and five new directives

notes_by_num.1: Firefox 31-34 is missing the plugin-types, child-src, frame-ancestors, base-uri, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox 35 is missing the plugin-types, child-src, frame-ancestors, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.3: Firefox 36-44 is missing the plugin-types and child-src directives.
notes_by_num.4: Chrome 36-38 & Opera 23-25 are missing the plugin-types, child-src, frame-ancestors, base-uri, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.5: Chrome 39 and Opera 26 are missing the plugin-types, child-src, base-uri, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.6: Firefox 38 on Android is missing the child-src directive.
notes_by_num.7: Firefox 45+ is missing the plugin-types directive.
notes_by_num.9: Edge has broken nonce support as it ignores nonces on sourced scripts.

name: cors
title: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing
description: Method of performing XMLHttpRequests across domains

notes_by_num.1: Does not support CORS for images in `<canvas>`
notes_by_num.2: Supported somewhat in IE8 and IE9 using the XDomainRequest object (but has [limitations](https://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/05/13/xdomainrequest-restrictions-limitations-and-workarounds.aspx))
notes_by_num.3: Does not support CORS for `<video>` in `<canvas>`: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=135379
notes_by_num.4: Does not support CORS for resources which redirect: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1346749

name: createimagebitmap
title: createImageBitmap
description: Create image bitmap with support for resizing and adjusting quality

notes_by_num.1: No support for options parameter, resizeWidth, resizeHeight, resizeQuality or SVGImageElement as Source Image
notes_by_num.2: No support for resizeWidth, resizeHeight, resizeQuality or SVGImageElement as Source Image
notes_by_num.3: No support for SVGImageElement as Source Image
notes_by_num.4: No support for resizeWidth, resizeHeight and resizeQuality. See [this bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1363861)
notes_by_num.5: No support for `createImageBitmap(source, options)` interface. see [this bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1335594)

name: credential-management
title: Credential Management API
description: API that provides a programmatic interface to the browser's credential manager. In short, an origin can request a user's credentials to sign them in, or can ask the browser to save credentials on the user's behalf. Both of these requests are user-mediated.

notes_by_num.1: In Chrome 51 ~ 56, PSL matched credentials are not supported. This means you cannot use credentials set on a.example.com in b.example.com. This is supported since Chrome 57.

name: cryptography
title: Web Cryptography
description: JavaScript API for performing basic cryptographic operations in web applications

notes_by_num.1: Support in IE11 is based on an older version of the specification.
notes_by_num.2: Support in Safari before version 11 was using the `crypto.webkitSubtle` prefix.
notes_by_num.3: In Edge 12-18, Web Crypto was not supported in Web Workers and Service Workers.

name: css-all
title: CSS all property
description: A shorthand property for resetting all CSS properties except for `direction` and `unicode-bidi`.

name: css-animation
title: CSS Animation
description: Complex method of animating certain properties of an element

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Android browser refers to buggy behavior in different scenarios.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support the `steps()`, `step-start` & `step-end` timing functions

name: css-any-link
title: CSS :any-link selector
description: The `:any-link` CSS pseudo-class matches all elements that match `:link` or `:visited`

name: css-appearance
title: CSS Appearance
description: The `appearance` property defines how elements (particularly form controls) appear by default. By setting the value to `none` the default appearance can be entirely redefined using other CSS properties.

notes_by_num.1: The appearance property is supported with the `none` value, but not `auto`.
notes_by_num.2: Microsoft Edge and IE Mobile support this property with the `-webkit-` prefix, rather than `-ms-` for interop reasons.
notes_by_num.3: `-moz-appearance:none` did not remove the dropdown arrow in the select tag

name: css-apply-rule
title: CSS @apply rule
description: Allows a set of CSS properties to be applied using a named variable

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental web platform features" flag under about:flags

name: css-at-counter-style
title: CSS Counter Styles
description: The @counter-style CSS at-rule allows custom counter styles to be defined. A @counter-style rule defines how to convert a counter value into a string representation.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to lacking support for [image symbols](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1024179)

name: css-backdrop-filter
title: CSS Backdrop Filter
description: Method of applying filter effects (like blur, grayscale or hue) to content/elements below the target element.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag
notes_by_num.2: Currently only supported with the `-webkit-` prefix (not -ms-)
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled by setting the `layout.css.backdrop-filter.enabled` and `gfx.webrender.all` preference to `true` in about:config.

name: css-background-offsets
title: CSS background-position edge offsets
description: Allows CSS background images to be positioned relative to the specified edge using the 3 to 4 value syntax. For example: `background-position: right 5px bottom 5px;` for positioning 5px from the bottom-right corner.

name: css-backgroundblendmode
title: CSS background-blend-mode
description: Allows blending between CSS background images, gradients, and colors.

notes_by_num.1: Partial in Safari refers to not supporting the `hue`, `saturation`, `color`, and `luminosity` blend modes.
notes_by_num.2: Chrome 46 has some [serious bugs](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=543583) with multiply, difference, and exclusion blend modes

name: css-boxdecorationbreak
title: CSS box-decoration-break
description: Controls whether the box's margins, borders, padding, and other decorations wrap the broken edges of the box fragments (when the box is split by a break (page/column/region/line).

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to working for inline elements but not across column or page breaks.

name: css-boxshadow
title: CSS3 Box-shadow
description: Method of displaying an inner or outer shadow effect to elements

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Safari, iOS Safari and Android Browser refers to missing "inset", blur radius value, and multiple shadow support.

name: css-canvas
title: CSS Canvas Drawings
description: Method of using HTML5 Canvas as a background image. Not currently part of any specification.

name: css-caret-color
title: CSS caret-color
description: The `caret-color` property allows the color to be set of the caret (blinking text insertion pointer) in an editable text area.

name: css-case-insensitive
title: Case-insensitive CSS attribute selectors
description: Including an `i` before the `]` in a CSS attribute selector causes the attribute value to be matched in an ASCII-case-insensitive manner. For example, `[b="xyz" i]` would match both `<a b="xyz">` and `<a b="XYZ">`.

name: css-clip-path
title: CSS clip-path property (for HTML)
description: Method of defining the visible region of an HTML element using SVG or a shape definition.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only supporting the `url()` syntax.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to supporting shapes and the `url(#foo)` syntax for inline SVG, but not shapes in external SVGs.
notes_by_num.3: Supports shapes behind the `layout.css.clip-path-shapes.enabled` flag
notes_by_num.4: Partial support can be enabled on MS Edge with the Enable CSS Clip-Path Flag
notes_by_num.5: While Edge doesn't seem to recognize any `<basic-shape>` function, it does allow you to use `polygon()` in HTML and SVG

name: css-color-adjust
title: CSS color-adjust
description: The `color-adjust` (or `-webkit-print-color-adjust` as prefixed in WebKit/Blink browsers) property is a non-standard CSS extension that can be used to force printing of background colors and images.

name: css-color-function
title: CSS color function
description: The CSS `color()` function allows the browser to display colors in any color space, such as the P3 color space which can display colors outside of the default sRGB color space.

name: css-conic-gradients
title: CSS Conical Gradients
description: Method of defining a conical or repeating conical color gradient as a CSS image.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag
notes_by_num.2: Does not support multi-position color stops
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled with the `layout.css.conic-gradient.enabled` flag

name: css-containment
title: CSS Containment
description: The CSS `contain` property lets developers limit the scope of the browser's styles, layout and paint work for faster and more efficient rendering.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in older Gecko engines with the `layout.css.contain.enabled` flag in about:config
notes_by_num.2: Partially supported in Firefox by enabling "layout.css.contain.enabled" in about:config

name: css-content-visibility
title: CSS content-visibility
description: Provides control over when elements are rendered, so rendering can be skipped for elements not yet in the user's viewport.

name: css-counters
title: CSS Counters
description: Method of controlling number values in generated content, using the `counter-reset` and `counter-increment` properties.

name: css-crisp-edges
title: Crisp edges/pixelated images
description: Scales images with an algorithm that preserves edges and contrast, without smoothing colors or introducing blur. This is intended for images such as pixel art. Official values that accomplish this for the `image-rendering` property are `crisp-edges` and `pixelated`.

notes_by_num.1: Supported using the non-standard value `-webkit-optimize-contrast`
notes_by_num.2: Internet Explorer accomplishes support using the non-standard declaration `-ms-interpolation-mode: nearest-neighbor`
notes_by_num.3: Supports the `crisp-edges` value, but not `pixelated`.
notes_by_num.4: Supports the `pixelated` value, but not `crisp-edges`.
notes_by_num.5: Only works on ``, not CSS backgrounds or ``.
notes_by_num.6: Only works on `` and CSS backgrounds, _not_ ``.

name: css-cross-fade
title: CSS Cross-Fade Function
description: Image function to create a "crossfade" between images. This allows one image to transition (fade) into another based on a percentage value.

name: css-default-pseudo
title: :default CSS pseudo-class
description: The `:default` pseudo-class matches checkboxes and radio buttons which are checked by default, `<option>`s with the `selected` attribute, and the default submit button (if any) of a form.

notes_by_num.1: Does not match `<input type="checkbox" checked>` or `<input type="radio" checked>`
notes_by_num.2: Does not match the default submit button of a form

name: css-descendant-gtgt
title: Explicit descendant combinator >>
description: An explicit, non-whitespace spelling of the descendant combinator. `A >> B` is equivalent to `A B`.

name: css-deviceadaptation
title: CSS Device Adaptation
description: A standard way to override the size of viewport in web page using the `@viewport` rule, standardizing and replacing Apple's own popular `<meta>` viewport implementation.

notes_by_num.1: IE only supports the 'width' and 'height' properties.
notes_by_num.2: Opera Mobile and Opera Mini only support the 'orientation' property.

name: css-dir-pseudo
title: :dir() CSS pseudo-class
description: Matches elements based on their directionality. `:dir(ltr)` matches elements which are Left-to-Right. `:dir(rtl)` matches elements which are Right-to-Left.

name: css-display-contents
title: CSS display: contents
description: `display: contents` causes an element's children to appear as if they were direct children of the element's parent, ignoring the element itself. This can be useful when a wrapper element should be ignored when using CSS grid or similar layout techniques.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to [severe implementation bug](https://hiddedevries.nl/en/blog/2018-04-21-more-accessible-markup-with-display-contents) that renders the content inaccessible.
notes_by_num.3: Safari support is buggy, see [WebKit bug 188259](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=188259) & [WebKit bug 193567](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=193567)

name: css-element-function
title: CSS element() function
description: This function renders a live image generated from an arbitrary HTML element

notes_by_num.1: In Firefox < 4, usage limited to the background and background-image CSS properties

name: css-env-function
title: CSS Environment Variables env()
description: Usage of environment variables like `safe-area-inset-top`.

notes_by_num.1: Supported as `constant()` instead of `env()`

name: css-exclusions
title: CSS Exclusions Level 1
description: Exclusions defines how inline content flows around elements. It extends the content wrapping ability of floats to any block-level element.

name: css-featurequeries
title: CSS Feature Queries
description: CSS Feature Queries allow authors to condition rules based on whether particular property declarations are supported in CSS using the @supports at rule.

name: css-filter-function
title: CSS filter() function
description: This function filters a CSS input image with a set of filter functions (like blur, grayscale or hue)

name: css-filters
title: CSS Filter Effects
description: Method of applying filter effects using the `filter` property to elements, matching filters available in SVG. Filter functions include blur, brightness, contrast, drop-shadow, grayscale, hue-rotate, invert, opacity, sepia and saturate.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox under the `layout.css.filters.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in MS Edge under the "Enable CSS filter property" flag.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Firefox before version 34 [only implemented the url() function of the filter property](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/filter#Browser_compatibility)
notes_by_num.4: Partial support refers to supporting filter functions, but not the `url` function.

name: css-first-letter
title: ::first-letter CSS pseudo-element selector
description: CSS pseudo-element that allows styling only the first "letter" of text within an element. Useful for implementing initial caps or drop caps styling.

notes_by_num.1: Excludes punctuation immediately after the first letter from the match. (The spec says it should be included in the match.)
notes_by_num.2: Acts like the first character is always a letter even when it's not. For example, given "!,X;", "!," is matched instead of the entire string.
notes_by_num.3: Only recognizes the deprecated :first-letter pseudo-class, not the ::first-letter pseudo-element.
notes_by_num.4: Only matches the very first character. The spec says that surrounding punctuation should also match.

name: css-first-line
title: CSS first-line pseudo-element
description: Allows styling specifically for the first line of text using the `::first-line` pseudo-element. Note that only a limited set of properties can be applied.

notes_by_num.1: IE8 only supports the single-colon CSS 2.1 syntax (i.e. `:first-line`). It does not support the double-colon CSS3 syntax (i.e. `::first-line`).

name: css-fixed
title: CSS position:fixed
description: Method of keeping an element in a fixed location regardless of scroll position

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older iOS Safari refers to [buggy behavior](http://remysharp.com/2012/05/24/issues-with-position-fixed-scrolling-on-ios/).
notes_by_num.2: Only works in Android 2.1 thru 2.3 by using the following meta tag: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, user-scalable=no">.
notes_by_num.3: Android 4.0-4.3 [ignore transforms and margin:auto on position:fixed elements](https://codepen.io/mattiacci/pen/mPRKZY).
notes_by_num.4: in Safari 9.1, having a `position:fixed`-element inside an animated element, [may cause the `position:fixed`-element to not appear](https://jsbin.com/fuxipax).

name: css-focus-visible
title: :focus-visible CSS pseudo-class
description: The `:focus-visible` pseudo-class applies while an element matches the `:focus` pseudo-class, and the UA determines via heuristics that the focus should be specially indicated on the element (typically via a â€œfocus ringâ€).

notes_by_num.1: As `:-moz-focusring`
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags

name: css-focus-within
title: :focus-within CSS pseudo-class
description: The `:focus-within` pseudo-class matches elements that either themselves match `:focus` or that have descendants which match `:focus`.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag

name: css-font-rendering-controls
title: CSS font-rendering controls
description: `@font-face` descriptor (currently defined as `font-display`) that allows control over how a downloadable font renders before it is fully loaded.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `layout.css.font-display.enabled` flag

name: css-font-stretch
title: CSS font-stretch
description: If a font has multiple types of variations based on the width of characters, the `font-stretch` property allows the appropriate one to be selected. The property in itself does not cause the browser to stretch to a font.

name: css-gencontent
title: CSS Generated content for pseudo-elements
description: Method of displaying text or images before or after the given element's contents using the ::before and ::after pseudo-elements. All browsers with support also support the `attr()` notation in the `content` property.

notes_by_num.1: IE8 only supports the single-colon CSS 2.1 syntax (i.e. :pseudo-class). It does not support the double-colon CSS3 syntax (i.e. ::pseudo-element).

name: css-gradients
title: CSS Gradients
description: Method of defining a linear or radial color gradient as a CSS image.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Opera 11.10 and 11.50 also refers to only having support for linear gradients.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari and Older Firefox versions refers to not using premultiplied colors which results in unexpected behavior when using the transparent keyword as advised by the [spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/CR-css3-images-20120417/#color-stop-syntax).
notes_by_num.3: Implements an earlier prefixed syntax as `-webkit-gradient`

name: css-grid
title: CSS Grid Layout (level 1)
description: Method of using a grid concept to lay out content, providing a mechanism for authors to divide available space for layout into columns and rows using a set of predictable sizing behaviors. Includes support for all `grid-*` properties and the `fr` unit.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE refers to supporting an [older version](https://www.w3.org/TR/2011/WD-css3-grid-layout-20110407/) of the specification.
notes_by_num.3: Enabled in Firefox through the `layout.css.grid.enabled ` flag
notes_by_num.4: There are some bugs with overflow ([1356820](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1356820), [1348857](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1348857), [1350925](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1350925))

name: css-hanging-punctuation
title: CSS hanging-punctuation
description: Allows some punctuation characters from start (or the end) of text elements to be placed "outside" of the box in order to preserve the reading flow.

name: css-has
title: :has() CSS relational pseudo-class
description: Only select elements containing specified content. For example, `a:has(>img)` selects all `` elements that contain an `` child.

name: css-hyphens
title: CSS Hyphenation
description: Method of controlling when words at the end of lines should be hyphenated using the "hyphens" property.

notes_by_num.1: Only supported on Android & Mac platforms (and only the "auto" value) for now. [See commit](https://crrev.com/ed7e106e0e48b3afb160a5bdbb37649e307d2b05) & related [bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=652964).

name: css-image-orientation
title: CSS3 image-orientation
description: CSS property used generally to fix the intended orientation of an image. This can be done using 90 degree increments or based on the image's EXIF data using the "from-image" value.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in iOS refers to the browser using EXIF data by default, though it does not actually support the property.
notes_by_num.2: Chrome/Edge has [a bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1082669) where the browser is not maintaining the imageâ€™s aspect ratio when `object-fit: cover` and `image-orientation: from-image` are used together.

name: css-image-set
title: CSS image-set
description: Method of letting the browser pick the most appropriate CSS background image from a given set, primarily for high PPI screens.

notes_by_num.1: Safari's implementation does not completely match the spec, in that only URLs are accepted for the image value and only 'x' is accepted as a resolution. See https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=160934.

name: css-in-out-of-range
title: :in-range and :out-of-range CSS pseudo-classes
description: If a temporal or number `<input>` has `max` and/or `min` attributes, then `:in-range` matches when the value is within the specified range and `:out-of-range` matches when the value is outside the specified range. If there are no range constraints, then neither pseudo-class matches.

notes_by_num.1: Opera Mini correctly applies style on initial load, but does not correctly update when value is changed.
notes_by_num.2: `:in-range` also incorrectly matches temporal and `number` inputs which don't have `min` or `max` attributes. See [Edge bug](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/7200501/), [Chrome bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=603268), [WebKit bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=156558).
notes_by_num.3: `:in-range` and `:out-of-range` incorrectly match inputs which are disabled or readonly. See [Edge bug](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/7190958/), [Mozilla bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1264157), [WebKit bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=156530), [Chrome bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=602568).

name: css-indeterminate-pseudo
title: :indeterminate CSS pseudo-class
description: The `:indeterminate` pseudo-class matches indeterminate checkboxes, indeterminate `<progress>` bars, and radio buttons with no checked button in their radio button group.

notes_by_num.1: Doesn't match radio buttons whose radio button group lacks a checked radio button
notes_by_num.2: Doesn't support the `<progress>` element
notes_by_num.3: Doesn't match indeterminate `<progress>` bars

name: css-initial-letter
title: CSS Initial Letter
description: Method of creating an enlarged cap, including a drop or raised cap, in a robust way.

notes_by_num.1: Safari implementation is incomplete. Does not allow applying web fonts to the initial letter.

name: css-initial-value
title: CSS initial value
description: A CSS value that will apply a property's initial value as defined in the CSS specification that defines the property

notes_by_num.1: Not supported on `quotes` property

name: css-letter-spacing
title: letter-spacing CSS property
description: Controls spacing between characters of text (i.e. "tracking" in typographical terms). Not to be confused with kerning.

notes_by_num.1: Truncates or rounds fractional portions of values

name: css-line-clamp
title: CSS line-clamp
description: Proprietary and undocumented CSS property that will contain text to a given amount of lines when used in combination with `display: -webkit-box`. It will end with ellipsis when `text-overflow: ellipsis` is included.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in MS Edge with `-webkit-` prefix only (not with `-ms-`)

name: css-logical-props
title: CSS Logical Properties
description: Logical properties and values provide control of layout through logical, rather than physical, direction and dimension mappings. These properties are `writing-mode` relative equivalents of their corresponding physical properties.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the *-start, and *-end values for `margin`, `border` and `padding`, not the inline/block type values as defined in the spec.
notes_by_num.2: Like #1 but also supports `*-before` and `*-end` for `*-block-start` and `*-block-end` properties as well as `start` and `end` values for `text-align`
notes_by_num.3: Does not support the `margin-block`, `margin-inline`, `padding-inline`, or any of the `inset` shorthand properties. Supported in newer Chromium browsers behind the `#enable-experimental-web-platform-features` flag
notes_by_num.4: Does not support the `padding-block`, `padding-inline`, or any `inset` property. Supported in newer Chromium browsers behind the `#enable-experimental-web-platform-features` flag
notes_by_num.5: Does not support the `border-start-start-radius`, `border-start-end-radius`, `border-end-start-radius` and `border-end-end-radius` property.

name: css-marker-pseudo
title: CSS ::marker pseudo-element
description: The `::marker` pseudo-element allows list item markers to be styled or have their content value customized.

notes_by_num.1: Safari supports [the definition in the CSS Pseudo-Elements Module Level 4](https://www.w3.org/TR/css-pseudo-4/#marker-pseudo) instead of one in the List module due to the flux definition in it.

name: css-masks
title: CSS Masks
description: Method of displaying part of an element, using a selected image as a mask

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in WebKit/Blink browsers refers to supporting the mask-image and mask-box-image properties, but lacking support for other parts of the spec.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Firefox refers to only support for inline SVG mask elements i.e. mask: url(#foo).
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to supporting the mask-box-image shorthand but not the longhand properties
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled in MS edge behind the "Enable CSS Masking" flag.
notes_by_num.5: Partial support refers to supporting mask-image and mask-size
notes_by_num.6: Partial support refers to supporting mask-image, mask-size, mask-position, mask-repeat and mask-composite
notes_by_num.7: Edge also recognizes and supports all the `-webkit-` prefixed equivalents of the unprefixed properties for site compatibility

name: css-matches-pseudo
title: :is() CSS pseudo-class
description: The `:is()` (formerly `:matches()`, formerly `:any()`) pseudo-class checks whether the element at its position in the outer selector matches any of the selectors in its selector list. It's useful syntactic sugar that allows you to avoid writing out all the combinations manually as separate selectors. The effect is similar to nesting in Sass and most other CSS preprocessors.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the deprecated `:-webkit-any()` pseudo-class
notes_by_num.2: Only supports the deprecated `:-webkit-any()` and `:-matches()` pseudo-classes
notes_by_num.3: Only supports the deprecated `:-moz-any()` pseudo-class.
notes_by_num.4: Also supports the deprecated `:-webkit-any()` pseudo-class
notes_by_num.5: Also supports the deprecated `:-matches()` pseudo-class
notes_by_num.6: Also supports the deprecated `:-moz-any()` pseudo-class.
notes_by_num.7: Support for `:is()` can be enabled with the `Experimental Web Platform features` flag

name: css-math-functions
title: CSS math functions min(), max() and clamp()
description: More advanced mathematical expressions in addition to `calc()`

notes_by_num.1: Safari did not support `clamp()`

name: css-media-interaction
title: Media Queries: interaction media features
description: Allows a media query to be set based on the presence and accuracy of the user's pointing device, and whether they have the ability to hover over elements on the page. This includes the `pointer`, `any-pointer`, `hover`, and `any-hover` media features.

name: css-media-resolution
title: Media Queries: resolution feature
description: Allows a media query to be set based on the device pixels used per CSS unit. While the standard uses `min`/`max-resolution` for this, some browsers support the older non-standard `device-pixel-ratio` media query.

notes_by_num.1: Supports the `dpi` unit, but does not support `dppx` or `dpcm` units.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox before 16 supports only `dpi` unit, but you can set `2dppx` per `min--moz-device-pixel-ratio: 2`
notes_by_num.3: Supports the non-standard `min`/`max-device-pixel-ratio`

name: css-mediaqueries
title: CSS3 Media Queries
description: Method of applying styles based on media information. Includes things like page and device dimensions

notes_by_num.1: Does not support nested media queries
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to only acknowledging different media rules on page reload

name: css-mixblendmode
title: Blending of HTML/SVG elements
description: Allows blending between arbitrary SVG and HTML elements

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Partial in Safari refers to not supporting the `hue`, `saturation`, `color`, and `luminosity` blend modes.

name: css-motion-paths
title: CSS Motion Path
description: Allows elements to be animated along SVG paths or shapes via the `offset-path` property. Originally defined as the `motion-path` property.

notes_by_num.1: Requires the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag to be enabled

name: css-namespaces
title: CSS namespaces
description: Using the `@namespace` at-rule, elements of other namespaces (e.g. SVG) can be targeted using the pipe (`|`) selector.

name: css-not-sel-list
title: selector list argument of :not()
description: Selectors Level 3 only allowed `:not()` pseudo-class to accept a single simple selector, which the element must not match any of. Thus, `:not(a, .b, [c])` or `:not(a.b[c])` did not work. Selectors Level 4 allows `:not()` to accept a list of selectors. Thus, `:not(a):not(.b):not([c])` can instead be written as `:not(a, .b, [c])` and `:not(a.b[c])` works as intended.

name: css-nth-child-of
title: selector list argument of :nth-child and :nth-last-child CSS pseudo-classes
description: The newest versions of `:nth-child()` and `:nth-last-child()` accept an optional `of S` clause which filters the children to only those which match the selector list `S`. For example, `:nth-child(1 of .foo)` selects the first child among the children that have the `foo` class (ignoring any non-`foo` children which precede that child). Similar to `:nth-of-type`, but for arbitrary selectors instead of only type selectors.

name: css-opacity
title: CSS3 Opacity
description: Method of setting the transparency level of an element

name: css-optional-pseudo
title: :optional CSS pseudo-class
description: The `:optional` pseudo-class matches form inputs (`<input>`, `<textarea>`, `<select>`) which are not `:required`.

notes_by_num.1: Does not match non-required `<select>`s

name: css-overflow
title: CSS overflow property
description: Originally a single property for controlling overflowing content in both horizontal & vertical directions, the `overflow` property is now a shorthand for `overflow-x` & `overflow-y`. The latest version of the specification also introduces the `clip` value that blocks programmatic scrolling.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the two value `overflow` shorthand
notes_by_num.2: Does not support the `clip` value

name: css-overflow-anchor
title: CSS overflow-anchor (Scroll Anchoring)
description:
Changes in DOM elements above the visible region of a scrolling box can result in the page moving while the user is in the middle of consuming the content.
By default, the value of  `overflow-anchor` is `auto`, it can mitigate this jarring user experience by keeping track of the position of an anchor node and adjusting the scroll offset accordingly

name: css-overscroll-behavior
title: CSS overscroll-behavior
description: CSS property to control the behavior when the scroll position of a scroll container reaches the edge of the scrollport.

notes_by_num.1: Supports the precursor version of the property: [`-ms-scroll-chaining`](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh772034%28v=vs.85%29.aspx), which works similarly. IE support is limited to Windows 8 & above
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `overscroll-behavior: none;` on the body element to prevent the overscroll glow and rubberbanding effects.
notes_by_num.3: Incorrectly treats `none` as `contain` see [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/overscroll-behavior#Browser_compatibility) and [Edge 18 changelog](https://aka.ms/devguide_edgehtml_18)

name: css-page-break
title: CSS page-break properties
description: Properties to control the way elements are broken across (printed) pages.

notes_by_num.1: Supports the `page-break-*` alias from the CSS 2.1 specification, but not the `break-*` properties from the latest spec.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `avoid` for `page-break-before` & `page-break-after` (only `page-break-inside`).
notes_by_num.3: Treats the `left` and `right` values like `always`.

name: css-paged-media
title: CSS Paged Media (@page)
description: CSS at-rule (`@page`) to define page-specific rules when printing web pages, such as margin per page and page dimensions.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the `size` property
notes_by_num.2: Does not appear to have a way to print web pages

name: css-paint-api
title: CSS Paint API
description: Allows programmatic generation of images used by CSS

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled using the Develop > Experimental Features menu.

name: css-placeholder
title: ::placeholder CSS pseudo-element
description: The ::placeholder pseudo-element represents placeholder text in an input field: text that represents the input and provides a hint to the user on how to fill out the form. For example, a date-input field might have the placeholder text `YYYY-MM-DD` to clarify that numeric dates are to be entered in year-month-day order.

notes_by_num.1: Firefox 18 and below supported the `:-moz-placeholder` pseudo-class rather than the `::-moz-placeholder` pseudo-element.

name: css-placeholder-shown
title: :placeholder-shown CSS pseudo-class
description: Input elements can sometimes show placeholder text as a hint to the user on what to type in. See, for example, the placeholder attribute in HTML5. The :placeholder-shown pseudo-class matches an input element that is showing such placeholder text.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to using the non-standard `:-moz-placeholder` name rather than `:placeholder-shown`.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE refers to using the non-standard `:-ms-input-placeholder` name rather than `:placeholder-shown`.

name: css-read-only-write
title: CSS :read-only and :read-write selectors
description: :read-only and :read-write pseudo-classes to match elements which are considered user-alterable

notes_by_num.1: Supports selector only for input and textarea fields, but not for contenteditable

name: css-rebeccapurple
title: Rebeccapurple color
description: The new color added in CSS Color Module Level 4

notes_by_num.1: Only works in IE11 for Windows 10, not older versions of Windows

name: css-reflections
title: CSS Reflections
description: Method of displaying a reflection of an element

name: css-regions
title: CSS Regions
description: Method of flowing content into multiple elements.

notes_by_num.1: Support is limited to using an iframe as a content source with the `-ms-flow-into: flow_name;` and `-ms-flow-from: flow_name;` syntax.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting the `region-fragment` property.

name: css-repeating-gradients
title: CSS Repeating Gradients
description: Method of defining a repeating linear or radial color gradient as a CSS image.

name: css-resize
title: CSS resize property
description: Method of allowing an element to be resized by the user, with options to limit to a given direction.

notes_by_num.1: Presto-based Opera 12.10+ currently only supports the resize property for textarea elements.

name: css-revert-value
title: CSS revert value
description: A CSS keyword value that resets a property's value to the default specified by the browser in its UA stylesheet, as if the webpage had not included any CSS. For example, `display:revert` on a `<div>` would result in `display:block`. This is in contrast to the `initial` value, which is simply defined on a per-property basis, and for `display` would be `inline`.

name: css-rrggbbaa
title: #rrggbbaa hex color notation
description: The CSS Color Module Level 4 defines new 4 & 8 character hex notation for color to include the opacity level.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental web platform features" flag.

name: css-scroll-behavior
title: CSSOM Scroll-behavior
description: Method of specifying the scrolling behavior for a scrolling box, when scrolling happens due to navigation or CSSOM scrolling APIs.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to support everything except of `Element.scrollIntoView()` and not together with pinch viewport.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Chrome and Opera behind the 'Smooth Scrolling' and/or 'Enable experimental web platform features' flag

name: css-scrollbar
title: CSS scrollbar styling
description: Methods of styling scrollbars' color and width.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports styling scrollbar colors through proprietary prefixed properties, no other properties to define the scrollbar's appearance. (not on standards track)
notes_by_num.2: Supports scrollbar styling via CSS [pseudo-properties](https://webkit.org/blog/363/styling-scrollbars/). (not on standards track)
notes_by_num.3: Scrollbar styling doesnâ€™t work in [WKWebView](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CB-10123)
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled by setting the layout.css.scrollbar-colors.enabled and layout.css.scrollbar-width.enabled flags to true.
notes_by_num.5: Firefox 63 supported scrollbar-face-color and scrollbar-track-color seperate properties (now dropped from the spec) instead of unified scrollbar-color property.
notes_by_num.6: Firefox neither supports `light` and `dark` values of scrollbar-color nor `<length>` values of scrollbar width

name: css-sel2
title: CSS 2.1 selectors
description: Basic CSS selectors including: `*` (universal selector), `>` (child selector), `:first-child`, `:link`, `:visited`, `:active`, `:hover`, `:focus`, `:lang()`, `+` (adjacent sibling selector), `[attr]`, `[attr="val"]`, `[attr~="val"]`, `[attr|="bar"]`, `.foo` (class selector), `#foo` (id selector)

name: css-sel3
title: CSS3 selectors
description: Advanced element selection using selectors including: `[foo^="bar"]`, `[foo$="bar"]`, `[foo*="bar"]`, `:root`, `:nth-child()`,  `:nth-last-child()`, `:nth-of-type()`, `:nth-last-of-type()`, `:last-child`, `:first-of-type`, `:last-of-type`, `:only-child`, `:only-of-type`, `:empty`, `:target`, `:enabled`, `:disabled`, `:checked`, `:not()`, `~` (general sibling)

notes_by_num.1: IE7 and IE8 support only these CSS3 selectors: General siblings (`element1~element2`) and Attribute selectors `[attr^=val]`, `[attr$=val]`, and `[attr*=val]`

name: css-selection
title: ::selection CSS pseudo-element
description: The ::selection CSS pseudo-element applies rules to the portion of a document that has been highlighted (e.g., selected with the mouse or another pointing device) by the user.

name: css-shapes
title: CSS Shapes Level 1
description: Allows geometric shapes to be set in CSS to define an area for text to flow around. Includes properties `shape-outside`, `shape-margin` and `shape-image-threshold`

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Partially supported in Firefox by enabling "layout.css.shape-outside.enabled" in about:config

name: css-snappoints
title: CSS Scroll Snap
description: CSS technique that allows customizable scrolling experiences like pagination of carousels by setting defined snap positions.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE10 refers to support limited to touch screens.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE11 [documented here](https://web.archive.org/web/20160616212557/https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/444684/openwebref/CSS/scroll-snap-points/support.html)
notes_by_num.4: Partial support in Safari refers to not supporting the `none` keyword in `scroll-snap-points-x`, `scroll-snap-points-y` and `scroll-snap-coordinate`, and length keywords (`top`, `right`, etc.) in `scroll-snap-destination` and `scroll-snap-coordinate`.
notes_by_num.5: Supports properties from an [older version](https://www.w3.org/TR/2015/WD-css-snappoints-1-20150326/) of the spec.
notes_by_num.6: Partial support in IE & Edge refers to not supporting `scroll-snap-coordinate` and `scroll-snap-destination`.
notes_by_num.7: Available behind the "Experimental Web Platform features" feature flag

name: css-sticky
title: CSS position:sticky
description: Keeps elements positioned as "fixed" or "relative" depending on how it appears in the viewport. As a result the element is "stuck" when necessary while scrolling.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox by setting the about:config preference layout.css.sticky.enabled to true
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag
notes_by_num.3: Not supported on any `table` parts - See [Firefox bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=975644)
notes_by_num.4: Supported on `th` elements, but not `thead` or `tr` - See [Chrome bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=702927)
notes_by_num.5: Do not appear to support sticky table headers
notes_by_num.6: Supported on `th` elements, but not `thead` or `tr` - See [Edge bug](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/16765952/)

name: css-subgrid
title: CSS Subgrid
description: Feature of the CSS Grid Layout Module Level 2 that allows a grid-item with its own grid to align in one or both dimensions with its parent grid.

name: css-supports-api
title: CSS.supports() API
description: The CSS.supports() static methods returns a Boolean value indicating if the browser supports a given CSS feature, or not.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Presto-based Opera browsers refers to using an older API (`window.supportsCSS`)
notes_by_num.2: Does not support parentheses-less one-argument version.

name: css-table
title: CSS Table display
description: Method of displaying elements as tables, rows, and cells. Includes support for all `display: table-*` properties as well as `display: inline-table`

notes_by_num.1: Firefox 2 does not support `inline-table`

name: css-text-align-last
title: CSS3 text-align-last
description: CSS property to describe how the last line of a block or a line right before a forced line break when `text-align` is `justify`.

notes_by_num.1: In Internet Explorer, the start and end values are not supported.
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "Enable Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.3: Enabled through the "Enable Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in opera://flags

name: css-text-indent
title: CSS text-indent
description: The `text-indent` property applies indentation to lines of inline content in a block.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to supporting a `<length>` value, but not the `each-line` or `hanging` keywords.
notes_by_num.2: Support for `each-line` & `hanging` is available behind the Experimental Web Platform features flag

name: css-text-justify
title: CSS text-justify
description: CSS property to define how text should be justified when `text-align: justify` is set.

notes_by_num.1: Supports `inter-word`, but not `inter-character` or  `none`. Also supports the following unofficial values: `distribute` , `distribute-all-lines`, `distribute-center-last`, `inter-cluster`, `inter-ideograph`, `newspaper`. See [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/text-justify) for details.
notes_by_num.2: `inter-word` and `distribute` values supported behind the "Experimental platform features" flag but `distribute` support [is buggy](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=467406)
notes_by_num.3: Behind the "layout.css.text-justify.enabled" flag
notes_by_num.4: Supports `auto`, `none`, `inter-word`, `inter-character`, and `distribute` with the exact same meaning and behavior as `inter-character` for legacy reasons.

name: css-text-orientation
title: CSS text-orientation
description: The CSS `text-orientation` property specifies the orientation of text within a line. Current values only have an effect in vertical typographic modes (defined with the `writing-mode` property)

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled on firefox via the 'layout.css.vertical-text.enabled' flag in about:config.

name: css-textshadow
title: CSS3 Text-shadow
description: Method of applying one or more shadow or blur effects to text

notes_by_num.1: IE 10+ supports a fourth length value for the shadow's "spread". This is not (yet) part of the specification.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari 3.* refers to not supporting multiple shadows.

name: css-touch-action
title: CSS touch-action property
description: touch-action is a CSS property that controls filtering of gesture events, providing developers with a declarative mechanism to selectively disable touch scrolling (in one or both axes) or double-tap-zooming.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox behind the `layout.css.touch_action.enabled` flag, Firefox for Windows 8 Touch ('Metro') enabled by default.
notes_by_num.2: IE10+ has already supported these property which are not in standard at present such as `double-tap-zoom`, `cross-slide-x`, `cross-slide-y`.
notes_by_num.3: iOS Safari only supports `auto` and `manipulation`.
notes_by_num.4: Not applicable to Firefox platforms that support neither pointer nor touch events.

name: css-transitions
title: CSS3 Transitions
description: Simple method of animating certain properties of an element, with ability to define property, duration, delay and timing function.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the `steps()`, `step-start` & `step-end` timing functions

name: css-unset-value
title: CSS unset value
description: A CSS value that's the same as "inherit" if a property is inherited or "initial" if a property is not inherited.

name: css-variables
title: CSS Variables (Custom Properties)
description: Permits the declaration and usage of cascading variables in stylesheets.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in `chrome://flags`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support is due to bugs present (see known issues)

name: css-widows-orphans
title: CSS widows & orphans
description: CSS properties to control when lines break across pages or columns by defining the amount of lines that must be left before or after the break.

notes_by_num.1: Supports widows & orphans properties, but due to not supporting CSS multi-columns the support is only for page breaks (for print)

name: css-writing-mode
title: CSS writing-mode property
description: Property to define whether lines of text are laid out horizontally or vertically and the direction in which blocks progress.

notes_by_num.1: Internet Explorer supports different values from an [earlier version of the spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/2003/CR-css3-text-20030514/#Progression), which originated from SVG.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Firefox under the `layout.css.vertical-text.enabled` flag

name: css-zoom
title: CSS zoom
description: Non-standard method of scaling content.

notes_by_num.1: The `-ms-zoom` property is an extension to CSS, and can be used as a synonym for `zoom` in IE8 Standards mode.

name: css3-attr
title: CSS3 attr() function for all properties
description: While `attr()` is supported for effectively all browsers for the `content` property, CSS Values and Units Level 3 adds the ability to use `attr()` on **any** CSS property, and to use it for non-string values (e.g. numbers, colors).

name: css3-boxsizing
title: CSS3 Box-sizing
description: Method of specifying whether or not an element's borders and padding should be included in size units

name: css3-colors
title: CSS3 Colors
description: Method of describing colors using Hue, Saturation and Lightness (hsl()) rather than just RGB, as well as allowing alpha-transparency with rgba() and hsla().

name: css3-cursors
title: CSS3 Cursors (original values)
description: CSS3 cursor values added in the 2004 spec, including none, context-menu, cell, vertical-text, alias, copy, no-drop, not-allowed, nesw-resize, nwse-resize, col-resize, row-resize and all-scroll.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to no support for the alias, cell, copy, ew-resize, ns-resize, nesw-resize, nwse-resize or context-menu cursors.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting 'none'.

name: css3-cursors-grab
title: CSS grab & grabbing cursors
description: Support for the `grab` & `grabbing` values for the `cursor` property. Used to indicate that something can be grabbed (dragged to be moved).

name: css3-cursors-newer
title: CSS3 Cursors: zoom-in & zoom-out
description: Support for `zoom-in`, `zoom-out` values for the CSS3 `cursor` property.

name: css3-tabsize
title: CSS3 tab-size
description: Method of customizing the width of the tab character. Only effective using 'white-space: pre' or 'white-space: pre-wrap'.

notes_by_num.1: Partial refers to supporting `<integer>` but not `<length>` values.

name: currentcolor
title: CSS currentColor value
description: A CSS value that will apply the existing `color` value to other properties like `background-color`, etc.

name: custom-elements
title: Custom Elements (deprecated V0 spec)
description: Original V0 version of the custom elements specification. See [Custom Elements V1](#feat=custom-elementsv1) for support for the latest version.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "dom.webcomponents.enabled" preference in about:config
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "dom.webcomponents.customelements.enabled" preference in about:config

name: custom-elementsv1
title: Custom Elements (V1)
description: Method of defining new HTML tags.

notes_by_num.1: Supports "Autonomous custom elements" but not "Customized built-in elements".
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the `dom.webcomponents.enabled` preference in `about:config`.
notes_by_num.3: Enabled through the `dom.webcomponents.customelements.enabled` preference in `about:config`.

name: customevent
title: CustomEvent
description: A DOM event interface that can carry custom application-defined data.

notes_by_num.1: While a `window.CustomEvent` object exists, it cannot be called as a constructor. Instead of `new CustomEvent(...)`, you must use `e = document.createEvent('CustomEvent')` and then `e.initCustomEvent(...)`
notes_by_num.2: There is no `window.CustomEvent` object, but `document.createEvent('CustomEvent')` still works.

name: datalist
title: Datalist element
description: Method of setting a list of options for a user to select in a text field, while leaving the ability to enter a custom value.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to [a bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=773041) where long lists of items are unscrollable resulting in unselectable options.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE refers to [significantly buggy behavior](https://web.archive.org/web/20170121011936/http://playground.onereason.eu/2013/04/ie10s-lousy-support-for-datalists/) (IE11+ does send the input and change events upon selection).
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to no support for datalists on non-text fields (e.g. number, [range](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=841942), [color](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=960984)).
notes_by_num.4: Partial support in Edge refers [to disappearing option elements on focusing the input element via tab](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/20066595/).
notes_by_num.5: Supported through WKWebView and Safari but not through UIWebView
notes_by_num.6: In Firefox, autocomplete must be set to off to make dynamic datalist work due to [a bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1474137)

name: dataset
title: dataset & data-* attributes
description: Method of applying and accessing custom data to elements.

notes_by_num.1: While the HTML spec doesn't require it, these browsers also support `dataset` and `data-*` attributes on SVG elements, in compliance with [current plans for SVG2](https://www.w3.org/2015/01/15-svg-minutes.html#item03)

name: datauri
title: Data URIs
description: Method of embedding images and other files in webpages as a string of text, generally using base64 encoding.

notes_by_num.1: Support is limited to images and linked resources like CSS files, not HTML or JS files. Max URI length is 32KB.
notes_by_num.2: Support is limited to images and linked resources like CSS or JS, not HTML files. Maximum size limit is 4GB.
notes_by_num.3: SVGs with XML declarations are not displayed when used in data-urls

name: date-tolocaledatestring
title: Date.prototype.toLocaleDateString
description: Date method to generate a language sensitive representation of a given date, formatted based on a specified locale and options.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the `locale` or `options` parameters
notes_by_num.2: Does not support all locales correctly
notes_by_num.3: Does not support the `timeZone` option

name: details
title: Details & Summary elements
description: The <details> element generates a simple no-JavaScript widget to show/hide element contents, optionally by clicking on its child <summary> element.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Firefox through the `dom.details_element.enabled` flag
notes_by_num.2: 'toggle' event is not supported
notes_by_num.3: <summary> is not keyboard accessible
notes_by_num.4: Some versions of Safari display smaller font-size than intended when using `rem` units with system fonts. (See: https://colloq.io/blog/safaris-detailssummary-rem-font-size-issue)

name: deviceorientation
title: DeviceOrientation & DeviceMotion events
description: API for detecting orientation and motion events from the device running the browser.

notes_by_num.1: `compassneedscalibration` supported in IE11 only for compatible devices with Windows 8.1+.

name: devicepixelratio
title: Window.devicePixelRatio
description: Read-only property that returns the ratio of the (vertical) size of one physical pixel on the current display device to the size of one CSS pixel.

name: dialog
title: Dialog element
description: Method of easily creating custom dialog boxes to display to the user with modal or non-modal options. Also includes a `::backdrop` pseudo-element for behind the element.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox by enabling "dom.dialog_element.enabled" in about:config
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in `chrome://flags`
notes_by_num.3: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in `opera://flags`
notes_by_num.4: Enabled by default in Firefox Nightly only

name: dispatchevent
title: EventTarget.dispatchEvent
description: Method to programmatically trigger a DOM event.

notes_by_num.1: Supports Microsoft's proprietary [`EventTarget.fireEvent() method`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/fireEvent).

name: dnssec
title: DNSSEC and DANE
description: Method of validating a DNS response against a trusted root server. Mitigates various attacks that could reroute a user to a fake site while showing the real URL for the original site.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support DNSSEC but still benefits greatly from it, as most of the security improvements are gained in the DNS-network and not in the browser.
notes_by_num.2: Early versions of Chrome [experimented](https://www.imperialviolet.org/2011/06/16/dnssecchrome.html) with browser-level validation.

name: do-not-track
title: Do Not Track API
description: Allows the browser's Do Not Track setting to be queried via `navigator.doNotTrack`.

notes_by_num.1: IE 9 and 10 are vendor-prefixed as `navigator.msDoNotTrack`
notes_by_num.2: IE 11 and Edge 16- use `window.doNotTrack` instead of `navigator.doNotTrack`.
notes_by_num.3: Browsers based on Gecko versions prior to 32 used 'yes' and 'no' rather than '1' and '0'.
notes_by_num.4: Between versions 6.1.1 and 9.1.3, Safari supported an ultimately-rejected amendment to the spec, using `window.doNotTrack` rather than `navigator.doNotTrack`.

name: document-currentscript
title: document.currentScript
description: `document.currentScript` returns the `<script>` element whose script is currently being processed.

name: document-evaluate-xpath
title: document.evaluate & XPath
description: Allow nodes in an XML/HTML document to be traversed using XPath expressions.

name: document-execcommand
title: Document.execCommand()
description: Allows running commands to manipulate the contents of an editable region in a document switched to designMode

name: document-policy
title: Document Policy
description: A mechanism that allows developers to set certain rules and policies for a given site. The rules can change default browser behaviour, block certain features or set limits on resource usage. Document Policy is useful both for security and performance, and is similar to [Permissions Policy](#feat=permissions-policy).

notes_by_num.1: Chromium browsers only support the HTTP header

name: document-scrollingelement
title: document.scrollingElement
description: `document.scrollingElement` refers to the element that scrolls the document.

name: documenthead
title: document.head
description: Convenience property for accessing the `<head>` element

name: dom-manip-convenience
title: DOM manipulation convenience methods
description: jQuery-like methods on DOM nodes to insert nodes around or within a node, or to replace one node with another. These methods accept any number of DOM nodes or HTML strings as arguments. Includes: `ChildNode.before`, `ChildNode.after`, `ChildNode.replaceWith`, `ParentNode.prepend`, and `ParentNode.append`.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "Enable Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in chrome://flags

name: dom-range
title: Document Object Model Range
description: A contiguous range of content in a Document, DocumentFragment or Attr

name: domcontentloaded
title: DOMContentLoaded
description: JavaScript event that fires when the DOM is loaded, but before all page assets are loaded (CSS, images, etc.).

name: dommatrix
title: DOMMatrix
description: The `DOMMatrix` interface represents 4x4 matrices, suitable for 2D and 3D operations. Supersedes the `WebKitCSSMatrix` and `SVGMatrix` interfaces.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the `WebKitCSSMatrix` version of the interface, not `DOMMatrix`
notes_by_num.2: `WebKitCSSMatrix#skewX`, `WebKitCSSMatrix#skewY` are not supported
notes_by_num.3: Only supports the `DOMMatrix` version of the interface, not `WebKitCSSMatrix` (support required by spec for legacy reasons)
notes_by_num.4: Only replaces `WebkitCSSMatrix` and not `SVGMatrix`
notes_by_num.5: Does not support `fromMatrix()`, `fromFloat32Array()`, `fromFloat64Array()`, and `toJSON()` methods

name: download
title: Download attribute
description: When used on an anchor, this attribute signifies that the browser should download the resource the anchor points to rather than navigate to it.

name: dragndrop
title: Drag and Drop
description: Method of easily dragging and dropping elements on a page, requiring minimal JavaScript.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to no support for the `dataTransfer.files` or `.types` objects
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting `.setDragImage`
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to limited supported formats for `dataTransfer.setData`/`getData`.
notes_by_num.4: Not supported in Chromium browsers on Android 6 or older.

name: element-closest
title: Element.closest()
description: DOM method that returns the current element if it matches the given selector, or else the closest ancestor element that matches the given selector, or else null.

name: element-from-point
