title: document.elementFromPoint()
description: Given coordinates for a point relative to the viewport, returns the element that a click event would be dispatched at if the user were to click the point (in other words, the element that hit-testing would find).

name: element-scroll-methods
title: Scroll methods on elements (scroll, scrollTo, scrollBy)
description: Methods to change the scroll position of an element. Similar to setting `scrollTop` & `scrollLeft` properties, but also allows options to be passed to define the scroll behavior.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the `smooth` behavior option.

name: eme
title: Encrypted Media Extensions
description: The EncryptedMediaExtenstions API provides interfaces for controlling the playback of content which is subject to a DRM scheme.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the older event-based specification

name: eot
title: EOT - Embedded OpenType fonts
description: Type of font that can be derived from a regular font, allowing small files and legal use of high-quality fonts. Usage is restricted by the file being tied to the website

name: es5
title: ECMAScript 5
description: Full support for the ECMAScript 5 specification. Features include `Function.prototype.bind`, Array methods like `indexOf`, `forEach`, `map` & `filter`, Object methods like `defineProperty`, `create` & `keys`, the `trim` method on Strings and many more.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `parseInt()` ignoring leading zeros.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support Strict mode
notes_by_num.3: Does not support zero-width chars in identifiers & Immutable `undefined`
notes_by_num.4: IE8 has virtually no ES5 support, but does support `Object.defineProperty`, `Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor`, JSON parsing & Property access on strings

name: es6
title: ECMAScript 2015 (ES6)
description: Support for the ECMAScript 2015 specification. Features include Promises, Modules, Classes, Template Literals, Arrow Functions, Let and Const, Default Parameters, Generators, Destructuring Assignment, Rest & Spread, Map/Set & WeakMap/WeakSet and many more.

notes_by_num.1: Notable partial support in IE11 includes (at least some) support for `const`, `let`, block-level function declaration, typed arrays, `Map`, `Set` and `WeakMap`.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support [tail call optimization](https://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/#test-proper_tail_calls_%28tail_call_optimisation%29)
notes_by_num.3: Only has partial Symbol support and partial support for `RegExp.prototype` properties

name: es6-class
title: ES6 classes
description: ES6 classes are syntactical sugar to provide a much simpler and clearer syntax to create objects and deal with inheritance.

notes_by_num.1: Requires strict mode. Non-strict mode support is behind the flag 'Enable Experimental JavaScript', disabled by default.

name: es6-generators
title: ES6 Generators
description: ES6 Generators are special functions that can be used to control the iteration behavior of a loop. Generators are defined using a `function*` declaration.

name: es6-module
title: JavaScript modules via script tag
description: Loading JavaScript module scripts using `<script type="module">` Includes support for the `nomodule` attribute.

notes_by_num.1: Support can be enabled via `about:flags`
notes_by_num.2: Support can be enabled via `about:config`
notes_by_num.3: Support can be enabled via the `experimental-web-platform-features` flag
notes_by_num.4: Does not support the `nomodule` attribute
notes_by_num.5: A [polyfill is available](https://gist.github.com/samthor/64b114e4a4f539915a95b91ffd340acc) for Safari 10.1/iOS Safari 10.3
notes_by_num.6: `nomodule` scripts are not executed, but they're still fetched

name: es6-module-dynamic-import
title: JavaScript modules: dynamic import()
description: Loading JavaScript modules dynamically using the import() syntax

notes_by_num.1: Support can be enabled via `javascript.options.dynamicImport` flag. See [bug 1517546](https://bugzil.la/1517546).

name: es6-number
title: ES6 Number
description: Extensions to the `Number` built-in object in ES6, including constant properties `EPSILON`, `MIN_SAFE_INTEGER`, and `MAX_SAFE_INTEGER`, and methods ` isFinite`, `isInteger`, `isSafeInteger`, and `isNaN`.

notes_by_num.1: Partial refers to only supporting the `isFinite`, `isInteger`, and `isNaN` methods.
notes_by_num.2: Partial refers to supporting the same as #1 and the addition of the `EPSILON` property.
notes_by_num.3: Partial refers to supporting all new features except the `isSafeInteger` method.
notes_by_num.4: Partial refers to only supporting the `isFinite` and `isNaN` methods.

name: es6-string-includes
title: String.prototype.includes
description: The includes() method determines whether one string may be found within another string, returning true or false as appropriate.

name: eventsource
title: Server-sent events
description: Method of continuously sending data from a server to the browser, rather than repeatedly requesting it (EventSource interface, used to fall under HTML5)

name: extended-system-fonts
title: ui-serif, ui-sans-serif, ui-monospace and ui-rounded values for font-family
description: Allows more control when choosing system interface fonts

name: feature-policy
title: Feature Policy
description: This specification defines a mechanism that allows developers to selectively enable and disable use of various browser features and APIs. Feature Policy is deprecated and has been replaced with [Permissions Policy](#feat=permissions-policy) and [Document Policy](#feat=document-policy).

notes_by_num.1: Older Chromium browsers did not support the JS API.
notes_by_num.2: Safari and Firefox only supports the `allow` attribute on iframes.
notes_by_num.3: Safari doesn't support a [list of origins](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=189901) or a [wildcard](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=187816).
notes_by_num.4: Supports [Permissions Policy](#feat=permissions-policy), the main replacement for this spec.

name: fetch
title: Fetch
description: A modern replacement for XMLHttpRequest.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support can be enabled in Firefox with the `dom.fetch.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Only available in Chrome and Opera within ServiceWorkers.
notes_by_num.3: Available in Chrome and Opera within Window and Workers by enabling the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in `chrome://flags`
notes_by_num.4: Firefox <40 is not completely conforming to the specs and does not respect the <base> tag for relative URIs in fetch requests. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1161625
notes_by_num.5: Appears to exist in Safari Technology Preview but does not work in current build. Should work in [next preview build](https://twitter.com/xeenon/status/715379838081576960)
notes_by_num.6: Can be enabled in `about:flags`

name: fieldset-disabled
title: disabled attribute of the fieldset element
description: Allows disabling all of the form control descendants of a fieldset via a `disabled` attribute on the fieldset element itself.

notes_by_num.1: Text inputs that are descendants of a disabled fieldset appear disabled but the user can still interact with them. [See IE bug #962368.](https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedbackdetail/view/962368/can-still-edit-input-type-text-within-fieldset-disabled)
notes_by_num.2: File inputs that are descendants of a disabled fieldset appear disabled but the user can still interact with them. [See IE bug #817488.](https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedbackdetail/view/817488)

name: fileapi
title: File API
description: Method of manipulating file objects in web applications client-side, as well as programmatically selecting them and accessing their data.

notes_by_num.1: Does not have `FileReader` support.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support the `File` constructor

name: filereader
title: FileReader API
description: Method of reading the contents of a File or Blob object into memory

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `readAsBinaryString`, but `readAsBinaryString` [can be polyfilled](https://stackoverflow.com/q/31391207)

name: filereadersync
title: FileReaderSync
description: Allows files to be read synchronously in Web Workers

name: filesystem
title: Filesystem & FileWriter API
description: Method of reading and writing files to a sandboxed file system.

name: flac
title: FLAC audio format
description: Popular lossless audio compression format

notes_by_num.1: HTMLMediaElement.canPlayType('audio/flac') returns an empty string
notes_by_num.2: Only works on ChromeOS
notes_by_num.3: Supported only on macOS High Sierra or later

name: flexbox
title: CSS Flexible Box Layout Module
description: Method of positioning elements in horizontal or vertical stacks. Support includes all properties prefixed with `flex`, as well as `display: flex`, `display: inline-flex`, `align-content`, `align-items`, `align-self`, `justify-content` and `order`.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the [old flexbox](https://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-css3-flexbox-20090723) specification and does not support wrapping.
notes_by_num.2: Only supports the [2012 syntax](https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/WD-css3-flexbox-20120322/)
notes_by_num.3: Does not support flex-wrap, flex-flow or align-content properties
notes_by_num.4: Partial support is due to large amount of bugs present (see known issues)

name: flexbox-gap
title: gap property for Flexbox
description: `gap` for flexbox containers to create gaps/gutters between flex items

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Chrome via the `#enable-experimental-web-platform-features` flag in `chrome://flags`

name: flow-root
title: display: flow-root
description: The element generates a block container box, and lays out its contents using flow layout. It always establishes a new block formatting context for its contents. It provides a better solution to the most use cases of the "clearfix" hack.

name: focusin-focusout-events
title: focusin & focusout events
description: The `focusin` and `focusout` events fire just before the element gains or loses focus, and they bubble. By contrast, the `focus` and `blur` events fire after the focus has shifted, and don't bubble.

name: font-family-system-ui
title: system-ui value for font-family
description: Value for `font-family` that represents the default user interface font.

notes_by_num.1: Supported as the `-apple-system` value (only on macOS and iOS)
notes_by_num.2: Supported as the `BlinkMacSystemFont` value (only on macOS)

name: font-feature
title: CSS font-feature-settings
description: Method of applying advanced typographic and language-specific font features to supported OpenType fonts.

notes_by_num.1: From Gecko 2.0 (Firefox 4.0) to Gecko 14.0 (Firefox 14.0) included, Gecko supported an older syntax, slightly different from the modern one: https://hacks.mozilla.org/2010/11/firefox-4-font-feature-support/
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in older Chrome versions refers to lacking support in Mac OS X.

name: font-kerning
title: CSS3 font-kerning
description: Controls the usage of the kerning information (spacing between letters) stored in the font. Note that this only affects OpenType fonts with kerning information, it has no effect on other fonts.

notes_by_num.1: Disabled by default, can be enabled using preference layout.css.font-features.enabled - defaulting to true on Nightly and Aurora only.

name: font-loading
title: CSS Font Loading
description: This CSS module defines a scripting interface to font faces in CSS, allowing font faces to be easily created and loaded from script. It also provides methods to track the loading status of an individual font, or of all the fonts on an entire page.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `layout.css.font-loading-api.enabled` flag. Enabled by default in Firefox 41. See [this bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1149381)

name: font-size-adjust
title: CSS font-size-adjust
description: Method of adjusting the font size in a matter that relates to the height of lowercase vs. uppercase letters. This makes it easier to set the size of fallback fonts.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Does not appear to work on Firefox mobile, despite recognition of the property.

name: font-smooth
title: CSS font-smooth
description: Controls the application of anti-aliasing when fonts are rendered.

notes_by_num.1: WebKit implements something similar with a different name `-webkit-font-smoothing` and different values: `none`, `antialiased` and `subpixel-antialiased`.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox implements something similar with a different name `-moz-osx-font-smoothing` and different values: `auto`, `inherit`, `unset`, `grayscale`.
notes_by_num.3: Works only on Mac OS X platform.

name: font-unicode-range
title: Font unicode-range subsetting
description: This @font-face descriptor defines the set of Unicode codepoints that may be supported by the font face for which it is declared. The descriptor value is a comma-delimited list of Unicode range (<urange>) values. The union of these ranges defines the set of codepoints that serves as a hint for user agents when deciding whether or not to download a font resource for a given text run.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `layout.css.unicode-range.enabled` flag

name: font-variant-alternates
title: CSS font-variant-alternates
description: Controls the usage of alternate glyphs associated to alternative names defined in @font-feature-values for certain types of OpenType fonts.

notes_by_num.1: Low-level syntax available in [font-feature-settings](https://caniuse.com/#feat=font-feature) property equivalent to OpenType features: salt, ss01 through ss20, cv01 through cv99, swsh, cswh, ornm, nalt
notes_by_num.2: Experimental support available by enabling the layout.css.font-features.enabled flag

name: font-variant-numeric
title: CSS font-variant-numeric
description: CSS property that provides different ways of displaying numbers, fractions, and ordinal markers.

name: fontface
title: @font-face Web fonts
description: Method of displaying fonts downloaded from websites

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only supporting EOT fonts.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to only supporting SVG fonts.

name: form-attribute
title: Form attribute
description: Attribute for associating input and submit buttons with a form.

name: form-submit-attributes
title: Attributes for form submission
description: Attributes for form submission that may be specified on submit buttons. The attributes are: `formaction`, `formenctype`, `formmethod`, `formnovalidate`, and `formtarget`

name: form-validation
title: Form validation
description: Method of setting required fields and field types without requiring JavaScript. This includes preventing forms from being submitted when appropriate, the `checkValidity()` method as well as support for the `:invalid`, `:valid`, and `:required` CSS pseudo-classes.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to lack of notice when form with required fields is attempted to be submitted.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE10 mobile refers to lack of warning when blocking submission.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Opera Mini refers to only supporting the CSS pseudo classes.

name: forms
title: HTML5 form features
description: Expanded form options, including things like date pickers, sliders, validation, placeholders and multiple file uploads. Previously known as "Web forms 2.0".

name: fullscreen
title: Full Screen API
description: API for allowing content (like a video or canvas element) to take up the entire screen.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to supporting an earlier draft of the spec.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting `::backdrop`, and supporting the old `:full-screen` syntax rather than the standard `:fullscreen`.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to not returning a Promise, as specified in the latest version of the spec.
notes_by_num.4: Unprefixed support is available behind the `full-screen-api.unprefix.enabled` flag
notes_by_num.5: Partial support refers to supporting only iPad, not iPhone. Shows an overlay button which can not be disabled.

name: gamepad
title: Gamepad API
description: API to support input from USB gamepad controllers through JavaScript.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu

name: geolocation
title: Geolocation
description: Method of informing a website of the user's geographical location

notes_by_num.1: Only works on secure (https) servers

name: getboundingclientrect
title: Element.getBoundingClientRect()
description: Method to get the size and position of an element's bounding box, relative to the viewport.

notes_by_num.1: The returned object lacks `width` and `height` properties.
notes_by_num.2: Returns incorrect values for elements which have had CSS `transform`s applied to them.
notes_by_num.3: The returned object cannot have new properties added to it; it's not extensible.
notes_by_num.4: Existing properties of the returned object are immutable.
notes_by_num.5: The returned object lacks `x` & `y` values, though existing `top` & `left` values can be used instead.

name: getcomputedstyle
title: getComputedStyle
description: API to get the current computed CSS styles applied to an element. This may be the current value applied by an animation or as set by a stylesheet.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to requiring the second parameter to be included.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting getComputedStyle on pseudo-elements.

name: getelementsbyclassname
title: getElementsByClassName
description: Method of accessing DOM elements by class name

name: getrandomvalues
title: crypto.getRandomValues()
description: Method of generating cryptographically random values.

name: gyroscope
title: Gyroscope
description: Defines a concrete sensor interface to monitor the rate of rotation around the deviceâ€™s local three primary axes.

notes_by_num.1: Available by enabling the "Generic Sensor" experimental flag in `about:flags`

name: hardwareconcurrency
title: navigator.hardwareConcurrency
description: Returns the number of logical cores of the user's CPU. The value may be reduced to prevent device fingerprinting or because it exceeds the allowed number of simultaneous web workers.

notes_by_num.1: WebKit browsers clamp the maximum value returned to 2 on iOS devices and 8 on all others. Disabled in Safari behind the ENABLE_NAVIGATOR_HWCONCURRENCY build option.

name: hashchange
title: Hashchange event
description: Event triggered in JavaScript when the URL's hash has changed (for example: page.html#foo to page.html#bar)

name: heif
title: HEIF/ISO Base Media File Format
description: HEIF (High Efficiency Image File Format) is a standard developed by the Moving Picture Experts Group (MPEG) for storage and sharing of images and image sequences. Can use `.heif` or `.heic` file extensions.

notes_by_num.1: While supported natively in macOS High Sierra and iOS 11, the file format does not appear to be supported in Safari.

name: hevc
title: HEVC/H.265 video format
description: The High Efficiency Video Coding (HEVC) compression standard is a video compression format intended to succeed H.264

notes_by_num.1: Supported only for devices with [hardware support](https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/insider/forum/insider_apps-insider_wmp/windows-10-hevc-playback-yes-or-no/3c1ab780-a6b2-4b77-ac0f-9faeefd4680d)
notes_by_num.2: Reported to work in certain Android devices with hardware support
notes_by_num.3: Supported only on macOS High Sierra or later

name: hidden
title: hidden attribute
description: The `hidden` attribute may be applied to any element, and effectively hides elements similar to `display: none` in CSS.

name: high-resolution-time
title: High Resolution Time API
description: Method to provide the current time in sub-millisecond resolution and such that it is not subject to system clock skew or adjustments. Called using `performance.now()`

notes_by_num.1: In Firefox, the "privacy.reduceTimerPrecision" preference is enabled by default and defaults to 20us in Firefox 59; in 60 it will be 2ms.
notes_by_num.2: In Firefox, the "privacy.resistFingerprinting" preference changes the precision to 100ms or the value of "privacy.resistFingerprinting.reduceTimerPrecision.microseconds", whichever is larger.

name: history
title: Session history management
description: Method of manipulating the user's browser's session history in JavaScript using `history.pushState`, `history.replaceState` and the `popstate` event.

name: html-media-capture
title: HTML Media Capture
description: Facilitates user access to a device's media capture mechanism, such as a camera, or microphone, from within a file upload control.

notes_by_num.1: iOS6-10 do not support the capture attribute used to force capture straight from the device's camera or microphone. Also note that default video dimensions are 480x320 (4:3).
notes_by_num.2: Android 2.2-2.3 do not support the capture attribute
notes_by_num.3: Supports a "capture" button for any `<input type="file"> field, regardless of the whether the capture attribute is used.

name: html5semantic
title: HTML5 semantic elements
description: HTML5 offers some new elements, primarily for semantic purposes. The elements include: `section`, `article`, `aside`, `header`, `footer`, `nav`, `figure`, `figcaption`, `time`, `mark` & `main`.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to missing the default styling, as technically the elements are considered "[unknown](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLUnknownElement)". This is easily taken care of by manually setting the default `display` value for each tag.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to only the `<main>` element (added later to the spec) being "unknown", though it can still be used and styled.

name: http-live-streaming
title: HTTP Live Streaming (HLS)
description: HTTP-based media streaming communications protocol

name: http2
title: HTTP/2 protocol
description: Networking protocol for low-latency transport of content over the web. Originally started out from the SPDY protocol, now standardized as HTTP version 2.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Internet Explorer refers to being limited to Windows 10.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari refers to being limited to OS X 10.11 El Capitan and newer.
notes_by_num.3: Only supports HTTP/2 if the server supports protocol negotiation via ALPN.

name: http3
title: HTTP/3 protocol
description: Upcoming version of the HTTP networking protocol, which is currently a draft. Previously known as HTTP-over-QUIC. Uses QUIC as its transport layer protocol.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox via the `network.http.http3.enabled` pref in `about:config`.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled in Chrome pre-release channels via the `--enable-quic` & `--quic-version=h3-23` command line arguments.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Safari refers to being limited to macOS 11 Big Sur and later.

name: iframe-sandbox
title: sandbox attribute for iframes
description: Method of running external site pages with reduced privileges (e.g. no JavaScript) in iframes.

name: iframe-seamless
title: seamless attribute for iframes
description: The seamless attribute makes an iframe's contents actually part of a page, and adopts the styles from its hosting page. The attribute has been removed from both [the WHATWG](https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/331) and [the W3C](https://github.com/w3c/html/pull/325) HTML5 specifications.

notes_by_num.1: Hides the border of seamless iframes and recognizes the 'seamless' DOM property, but does not provide actual support.

name: iframe-srcdoc
title: srcdoc attribute for iframes
description: Override the content specified in the `src` attribute (if present) with HTML content within the attribute.

name: ime
title: Input Method Editor API
description: Provides scripted access to the Input Method Editor (IME). An IME is often used to input characters from East Asian languages by typing roman characters and selecting from the resulting suggestions.

notes_by_num.1: Prefixed implementation uses `msGetInputContext()` method from an earlier version of the spec to get the `InputMethodContext`, rather than the `inputMethodContext` attribute. Also includes support for `getCompositionAlternatives()` from the latest Editor'

name: img-naturalwidth-naturalheight
title: naturalWidth & naturalHeight image properties
description: Properties defining the intrinsic width and height of the image, rather than the displayed width & height.

name: imports
title: HTML Imports
description: Deprecated method of including and reusing HTML documents in other HTML documents. Superseded by ES modules.

notes_by_num.1: Firefox [has no plans to support HTML imports](https://hacks.mozilla.org/2014/12/mozilla-and-web-components/) though for now it can be enabled through the "dom.webcomponents.enabled" preference in about:config
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "Enable HTML Imports" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.3: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.4: Enabled through the "Enable HTML Imports" flag in opera://flags
notes_by_num.5: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in opera://flags

name: indeterminate-checkbox
title: indeterminate checkbox
description: Indeterminate checkboxes are displayed in a state which is distinct both from being checked or being unchecked. They are commonly used in hierarchical checkboxes to indicate that only some of the checkbox's descendants are checked.

name: indexeddb
title: IndexedDB
description: Method of storing data client-side, allows indexed database queries.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE 10 & 11 refers to a number of subfeatures [not being supported](https://indexdb-support-test.glitch.me/). Edge does not support IndexedDB inside blob web workers. [See issue](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/5942817/)
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari & iOS 8 & 9 refers to [seriously buggy behavior](http://www.raymondcamden.com/2014/09/25/IndexedDB-on-iOS-8-Broken-Bad/) as well as complete lack of support in WebViews.

name: indexeddb2
title: IndexedDB 2.0
description: Improvements to Indexed DB, including getAll(), renaming stores and indexes, and binary keys.

notes_by_num.1: Missing: IDBKeyRange includes(), renaming stores/indexes, binary keys, IDBObjectStore getKey(), IDBCursor continuePrimaryKey()
notes_by_num.2: Missing: Renaming stores/indexes, binary keys, IDBObjectStore getKey(), IDBCursor continuePrimaryKey()

name: inline-block
title: CSS inline-block
description: Method of displaying an element as a block while flowing it with text.

notes_by_num.1: Only supported in IE6 and IE7 on elements with a display of "inline" by default. [Alternative properties](http://blog.mozilla.com/webdev/2009/02/20/cross-browser-inline-block/) are available to provide complete cross-browser support.

name: innertext
title: HTMLElement.innerText
description: A property representing the text within a DOM element and its descendants. As a getter, it approximates the text the user would get if they highlighted the contents of the element with the cursor and then copied to the clipboard.

name: input-autocomplete-onoff
title: autocomplete attribute: on & off values
description: The `autocomplete` attribute for `input` elements indicates to the browser whether a value should or should not be autofilled when appropriate.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to ignoring the `off` value for password fields. [see related blog post](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2009/09/10/troubleshooting-stored-login-problems-in-ie.aspx)
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Chrome refers to the browser intentionally ignoring `autocomplete="off"` when the user uses the browser's autofill functionality. [see bug](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=468153#c29)
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Firefox refers to ignoring `autocomplete="off"` for login forms. [see bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=956906)
notes_by_num.4: Browser does not display previously submitted values as options with `on` value.
notes_by_num.5: Safari ignores the `off` value for [username, email and password fields](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22661977/disabling-safari-autofill-on-usernames-and-passwords)

name: input-color
title: Color input type
description: Form field allowing the user to select a color.

notes_by_num.1: Supported through WKWebView and Safari but not through UIWebView

name: input-datetime
title: Date and time input types
description: Form field widgets to easily allow users to enter a date, time or both, generally by using a calendar/time input widget. Refers to supporting the following input types: `date`, `time`, `datetime-local`, `month` & `week`.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Microsoft Edge refers to supporting `date`, `week`, and `month` input types, and not `time` and `datetime-local`.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in iOS Safari refers to not supporting the `week` input type, nor the `min`, `max` or `step` attributes
notes_by_num.3: Some modified versions of the Android 4.x browser do have support for date/time fields.
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `dom.forms.datetime` flag.
notes_by_num.5: Partial support refers to supporting `date` and `time` input types, but not `datetime-local`, `month` or `week`.
notes_by_num.6: Partial support in macOS Safari refers to not supporting the `week` and `month` input type

name: input-email-tel-url
title: Email, telephone & URL input types
description: Text input fields intended for email addresses, telephone numbers or URLs. Particularly useful in combination with [form validation](https://caniuse.com/#feat=form-validation)

notes_by_num.1: Does not provide an email-specific keyboard for email addresses

name: input-event
title: input event
description: The `input` event is fired when the user changes the value of an `<input>` element, `<select>` element, or `<textarea>` element. By contrast, the "change" event usually only fires after the form control has lost focus.

notes_by_num.1: Doesn't fire an `input` event when deleting text (via Backspace, Delete, Cut, etc.).
notes_by_num.2: Doesn't fire an `input` event when drag-and-dropping text into an `<input>` or `<textarea>`.
notes_by_num.3: `<select>` doesn't fire `input` events. See [MS Edge bug](https://developer.microsoft.com/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/4660045/) and [Firefox bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1024350).
notes_by_num.4: Doesn't fire an `input` event when (un)checking a checkbox or radio button, or when changing the selected file(s) of an `<input type="file">`. See [Chrome bug](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=534245), [WebKit bug #149398](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=149398), [WebKit bug #190223](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=190223) and [Firefox bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1206616).
notes_by_num.5: Doesn't fire an `input` event when (un)checking a checkbox or radio button. See [MS Edge bug](https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedback/details/1883692).
notes_by_num.6: Doesn't fire an `input` event when changing the selected file(s) of an `<input type="file">`. See [WebKit bug #149398](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=149398) and [WebKit bug #204292](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=204292).

name: input-file-accept
title: accept attribute for file input
description: Allows a filter to be defined for what type of files a user may pick with from an `<input type="file">` dialog

notes_by_num.1: Supports the type format (e.g. `image/*`) but not the extension format (e.g. `.png`)
notes_by_num.2: Offers appropriate file locations/input based on format type, but does not prevent other files from being selected.
notes_by_num.3: Does not allow any files to be picked at all
notes_by_num.4: Supports the type format but does not allow any file to be picked when using the extension format

name: input-file-directory
title: Directory selection from file input
description: The `webkitdirectory` attribute on the `<input type="file">` element allows entire directory with file contents (and any subdirectories) to be selected.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu

name: input-file-multiple
title: Multiple file selection
description: Allows users to select multiple files in the file picker.

notes_by_num.1: Not supported on Android 4.x and below, presumably an OS limitation. Only seems to work in Android 5.x for the Chrome browser.

name: input-inputmode
title: inputmode attribute
description: The `inputmode` attribute specifies what kind of input mechanism would be most helpful for users entering content into the form control.

notes_by_num.1: Support can be enabled via the `dom.forms.inputmode` flag

name: input-minlength
title: Minimum length attribute for input fields
description: Declares a lower bound on the number of characters a user can input.

name: input-number
title: Number input type
description: Form field type for numbers.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support increment/decrement, either via buttons in UI or via arrow up & down keys.
notes_by_num.2: UI widget does not take the "step", "min" or "max" attributes into account.
notes_by_num.3: Firefox doesn't support [autocomplete content via datalist](https://codepen.io/graste/pen/bNoVKW) elements.
notes_by_num.4: Does not include increment/decrement buttons, but does support increment/decrement via arrow up & down keys.

name: input-pattern
title: Pattern attribute for input fields
description: Allows validation of an input field based on a given regular expression pattern.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not displaying a message for invalid patterns
notes_by_num.2: Safari browsers support the `pattern` attribute but will still allow forms to be submitted if the pattern is incorrect. See the [form validation data](https://caniuse.com/#feat=form-validation) for details.

name: input-placeholder
title: input placeholder attribute
description: Method of setting placeholder text for text-like input fields, to suggest the expected inserted information.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to lacking placeholder support on textarea elements.

name: input-range
title: Range input type
description: Form field type that allows the user to select a value using a slider widget.

name: input-search
title: Search input type
description: Search field form input type. Intended to look like the underlying platform's native search field widget (if there is one). Other than its appearance, it's the same as an `<input type="text">`.

notes_by_num.1: Does not use a special search-specific UI for the field, just the same UI as a regular `<input type="text">`.

name: input-selection
title: Selection controls for input & textarea
description: Controls for setting and getting text selection via `setSelectionRange()` and the `selectionStart` & `selectionEnd` properties.

name: insert-adjacent
title: Element.insertAdjacentElement() & Element.insertAdjacentText()
description: Methods for inserting an element or text before or after a given element, or appending or prepending an element or text to a given element's list of children.

name: insertadjacenthtml
title: Element.insertAdjacentHTML()
description: Inserts a string of HTML into a specified position in the DOM relative to the given element.

notes_by_num.1: Throws an "Invalid target element for this operation." error [when called on a table, tbody, thead, or tr element.](https://johnresig.com/blog/dom-insertadjacenthtml/)

name: internationalization
title: Internationalization API
description: Locale-sensitive collation (string comparison), number formatting, and date and time formatting.

name: intersectionobserver
title: IntersectionObserver
description: API that can be used to understand the visibility and position of DOM elements relative to a containing element or to the top-level viewport. The position is delivered asynchronously and is useful for understanding the visibility of elements and implementing pre-loading and deferred loading of DOM content.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Firefox by setting the `about:config` preference `dom.IntersectionObserver.enabled` to true
notes_by_num.2: "Preliminary" support as feature is still in development
notes_by_num.3: `isIntersecting` property of `IntersectionObserverEntry` was not implemented, returning `undefined`
notes_by_num.4: IntersectionObserver does not trigger its callback in a Chrome background tab

name: intersectionobserver-v2
title: IntersectionObserver V2
description: Iteration on the original API that also reports if the element is covered by another element or has filters applied to it. Useful for blocking clickjacking attempts or tracking ad exposure.

name: intl-pluralrules
title: Intl.PluralRules API
description: API for plural sensitive formatting and plural language rules.

notes_by_num.1: Intl.PluralRules exists, but methods are not implemented.

name: intrinsic-width
title: Intrinsic & Extrinsic Sizing
description: Allows for the heights and widths to be specified in intrinsic values using the `max-content`, `min-content`, `fit-content` and `stretch` (formerly `fill`) properties.

notes_by_num.1: Firefox does not support the `height`/`min-height`/`max-height` properties, only `width`. See [test case](https://codepen.io/shshaw/pen/Kiwaz), [Firefox bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=567039).
notes_by_num.2: Firefox supports the `-moz-available` keyword rather than `stretch`. [Firefox bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1495868).
notes_by_num.3: Does not support the `flex-basis` property. See [specs](https://www.w3.org/TR/2015/WD-css-flexbox-1-20150514/#flex-basis-property), [Blink bug](https://codereview.chromium.org/1304853002/), [Firefox bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1055887).
notes_by_num.4: Chrome does not yet unprefix `stretch` (aka `fill`/`fill-available`), because the [CSSWG](https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-style/2015Aug/0127.html) is not ready for that yet. See [Chromium bug](https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/blink.git/+/bf119cdfece210e69c9a99af06f1b9981e2a1bc2).
notes_by_num.5: While still being affected by note 1, it is only for `-moz-fit-content` and `-moz-available`.

name: jpeg2000
title: JPEG 2000 image format
description: JPEG 2000 (JP2) was created by the Joint Photographic Experts Group committee in 2000 with the intention of superseding their original discrete cosine transform-based JPEG standard (created in 1992) with a newly designed, wavelet-based method. It offers some advantages in image fidelity over standard JPEG.

notes_by_num.1: Not supported by Safari for Windows

name: jpegxr
title: JPEG XR image format
description: The latest JPEG image format of Joint Photographic Experts Group which boasts better compression and supports lossless compression, alpha channel, and 48-bit deep color over normal jpg format.

name: js-regexp-lookbehind
title: Lookbehind in JS regular expressions
description: Zero-width assertion that ensures a pattern is preceded by another pattern in a JavaScript regular expression.

name: json
title: JSON parsing
description: Method of converting JavaScript objects to JSON strings and JSON back to objects using JSON.stringify() and JSON.parse()

notes_by_num.1: Requires document to be in IE8+ [standards mode](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc288325%28VS.85%29.aspx) to work in IE8.

name: justify-content-space-evenly
title: CSS justify-content: space-evenly
description: The "space-evenly" value for the `justify-content` property distributes the space between items evenly. It is similar to space-around but provides equal instead of half-sized space on the edges. Can be used in both CSS flexbox & grid.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in CSS Grid, but not Flexbox

name: kerning-pairs-ligatures
title: High-quality kerning pairs & ligatures
description: When used in HTML, the unofficial `text-rendering: optimizeLegibility` CSS property enables high-quality kerning and ligatures in certain browsers. Newer browsers have this behavior enabled by default.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Android browser versions is due to a serious bug where `text-rendering: optimizeLegibility` causes custom web fonts to not render.

name: keyboardevent-charcode
title: KeyboardEvent.charCode
description: A legacy `KeyboardEvent` property that gives the Unicode codepoint number of a character key pressed during a `keypress` event.

notes_by_num.1: Does not appear to support the `keypress` event at all

name: keyboardevent-code
title: KeyboardEvent.code
description: A `KeyboardEvent` property representing the physical key that was pressed, ignoring the keyboard layout and ignoring whether any modifier keys were active.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome & Opera through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag

name: keyboardevent-getmodifierstate
title: KeyboardEvent.getModifierState()
description: `KeyboardEvent` method that returns the state (whether the key is pressed/locked or not) of the given modifier key.

name: keyboardevent-key
title: KeyboardEvent.key
description: A `KeyboardEvent` property whose value is a string identifying the key that was pressed. Covers character keys, non-character keys (e.g. arrow keys), and dead keys.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to these versions of Firefox returning `"MozPrintableKey"` for all character keys.
notes_by_num.2: Has non-standard key identifiers and incorrect behaviour with AltGraph.

name: keyboardevent-location
title: KeyboardEvent.location
description: A `KeyboardEvent` property that indicates the location of the key on the input device. Useful when there are more than one physical key for the same logical key (e.g. left or right "Control" key; main or numpad "1" key).

notes_by_num.1: Only supports `KeyboardEvent.keyLocation` from an older draft of the DOM Level 3 Events spec instead.

name: keyboardevent-which
title: KeyboardEvent.which
description: A legacy `KeyboardEvent` property that is equivalent to either `KeyboardEvent.keyCode` or `KeyboardEvent.charCode` depending on whether the key is alphanumeric.

notes_by_num.1: `event.which` number for keys does not always match expected value (difference may be dependent on hardware vs. on-screen keyboard?).

name: lazyload
title: Resource Hints: Lazyload
description: Gives a hint to the browser to lower the loading priority of a resource. Please note that this is a legacy attribute, see the [`loading`](https://caniuse.com/#feat=loading-lazy-attr) attribute for the new standardized API.

name: let
title: let
description: Declares a variable with block level scope

notes_by_num.1: Supports a non-standard version that can only be used in script elements with a type attribute of `application/javascript;version=1.7`. As other browsers do not support these types of `script` tags this makes support useless for cross-browser support.
notes_by_num.2: Requires the â€˜Experimental JavaScript featuresâ€™ flag to be enabled
notes_by_num.3: Only supported in strict mode
notes_by_num.4: `let` bindings in for loops are incorrectly treated as function-scoped instead of block scoped.
notes_by_num.5: `let` variables are not bound separately to each iteration of `for` loops

name: link-icon-png
title: PNG favicons
description: Icon used by browsers to identify a webpage or site. While all browsers support the `.ico` format, the PNG format can be preferable.

notes_by_num.1: If both ICO and PNG are available, will use ICO over PNG if ICO has better matching sizes set.
notes_by_num.2: If both ICO and PNG are available, will ALWAYS use ICO file, regardless of sizes set.
notes_by_num.3: If multiple formats are available, will use the last one loaded, regardless of sizes (effectively picks at random).
notes_by_num.4: Does not use favicons at all (but may have alternative for bookmarks, etc.).

name: link-icon-svg
title: SVG favicons
description: Icon used by browsers to identify a webpage or site. While all browsers support the `.ico` format, the SVG format can be preferable to more easily support higher resolutions or larger icons.

notes_by_num.1: Does not use favicons at all
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Firefox before version 41 refers to only loading the SVG favicon the first time, but not [on subsequent loads](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=366324#c14).
notes_by_num.3: Safari 9+ has support for "[pinned tab](https://developer.apple.com/library/prerelease/content/releasenotes/General/WhatsNewInSafari/Articles/Safari_9_0.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40014305-CH9-SW20)" SVG icons, but this requires an unofficial `rel="mask-icon"` to be set and only works for all-black icons on Pinned Tabs.
notes_by_num.4: Requires the served mime-type to be 'image/svg+xml'.
notes_by_num.5: Chromium browsers serve the SVG in [secure static mode](https://svgwg.org/svg2-draft/conform.html#secure-static-mode), but apply SMIL animations using the document start time (0).

name: link-rel-dns-prefetch
title: Resource Hints: dns-prefetch
description: Gives a hint to the browser to perform a DNS lookup in the background to improve performance. This is indicated using `<link rel="dns-prefetch" href="https://example.com/">`

notes_by_num.1: IE9 [supported `dns-prefetch` as `prefetch`](https://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2012/03/01/ie10-beta-consumer-preview-minor-changes-changelist.aspx) as the former wasnâ€™t defined yet.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox only supports `dns-prefetch` on HTTP origins. HTTPS is unsupported.

name: link-rel-modulepreload
title: Resource Hints: modulepreload
description: Using `<link rel="modulepreload">`, browsers can be informed to prefetch module scripts without having to execute them, allowing fine-grained control over when and how module resources are loaded.

name: link-rel-preconnect
title: Resource Hints: preconnect
description: Gives a hint to the browser to begin the connection handshake (DNS, TCP, TLS) in the background to improve performance. This is indicated using `<link rel="preconnect" href="https://example-domain.com/">`

notes_by_num.1: Firefox 39 did not support 'crossorigin' attribute and preconnects were not processed by the preload parser. Both of these features were enabled in Firefox 41.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Edge 15+ refers to support for only the HTTP header format, not the `<link rel>` format.
notes_by_num.3: Appears to have [stopped working](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1543990) in Firefox at some point.

name: link-rel-prefetch
title: Resource Hints: prefetch
description: Informs the browsers that a given resource should be prefetched so it can be loaded more quickly. This is indicated using `<link rel="prefetch" href="(url)">`

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Safari as `LinkPrefetch` in the developer menu

name: link-rel-preload
title: Resource Hints: preload
description: Using `<link rel="preload">`, browsers can be informed to prefetch resources without having to execute them, allowing fine-grained control over when and how resources are loaded.

notes_by_num.1: Only cachable resources can be preloaded. This includes the following `as` values: script, style, image, video, audio, track, fetch, and font (note font/collection is not supported).
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu
notes_by_num.3: Disabled by default behind the `network.preload` flag.
notes_by_num.4: Partial support in Edge 17+ refers to support for only the HTML `<link rel>` format, not the HTTP header format.

name: link-rel-prerender
title: Resource Hints: prerender
description: Gives a hint to the browser to render the specified page in the background, speeding up page load if the user navigates to it. This is indicated using `<link rel="prerender" href="(url)">`

name: loading-lazy-attr
title: Lazy loading via attribute for images & iframes
description: The `loading` attributing on images & iframes gives authors control over when the browser should start loading the resource.

notes_by_num.1: Firefox only supports lazy loading for images
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled in Settings under the Safari > Advanced > Experimental Features menu.

name: localecompare
title: localeCompare()
description: The `localeCompare()` method returns a number indicating whether a reference string comes before or after or is the same as the given string in sort order.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports basic support without locale & options parameters.

name: magnetometer
title: Magnetometer
description: Defines a concrete sensor interface to measure magnetic field in the X, Y and Z axis.

notes_by_num.1: Available by enabling the "Generic Sensor Extra Classes" experimental flag in `about:flags`

name: matchesselector
title: matches() DOM method
description: Method of testing whether or not a DOM element matches a given selector. Formerly known (and largely supported with prefix) as matchesSelector.

name: matchmedia
title: matchMedia
description: API for finding out whether or not a media query applies to the document.

name: mathml
title: MathML
description: Special tags that allow mathematical formulas and notations to be written on web pages.

notes_by_num.1: Before version 4, Firefox only supports the XHTML notation
notes_by_num.2: Before version 10, Safari had issues rendering significant portions of the MathML torture test

name: maxlength
title: maxlength attribute for input and textarea elements
description: Declares an upper bound on the number of characters the user can input. Normally the UI ignores attempts by the user to type in additional characters beyond this limit.

notes_by_num.1: `<textarea>`'s' UI does not prevent the user from typing additional characters beyond the `maxlength` limit.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support the `HTMLTextAreaElement.maxLength` DOM property.
notes_by_num.3: Does not support [`ValidityState.tooLong`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ValidityState/tooLong). In some cases, this is because `.validity` is not supported in the first place.
notes_by_num.4: Does not support `ValidityState.tooLong` correctly in the (unlikely) case of the value being initially set too long, then changed by the user to a still incorrect state. See [Firefox bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1203844) and [MS Edge bug](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/4678527/).
notes_by_num.5: `<input>`'s UI does not prevent the user from typing additional characters beyond the `maxlength` limit between two existing characters of the string.
notes_by_num.6: Allows text beyond maxlength to be entered at first, but removes all characters past the maxlength when focus is lost.

name: media-fragments
title: Media Fragments
description: Allows only part of a resource to be shown, based on the fragment identifier in the URL. Currently support is primarily limited to video track ranges.

notes_by_num.1: Only appears to support the `#t=n,n` control for selecting a range of video, and possibly `track=(name)` & `id=(name)` (not yet tested)

name: mediacapture-fromelement
title: Media Capture from DOM Elements API
description: API to capture Real-Time video and audio from a DOM element, such as a `<video>`, `<audio>`, or `<canvas>` element via the `captureStream` method, in the form of a `MediaStream`

notes_by_num.1: Does not support capture from `<video>`/`<audio>`
notes_by_num.2: Capture from `<video>`/`<audio>` can be enabled via the Experimental Web Platform Features flag.

name: mediarecorder
title: MediaRecorder API
description: The MediaRecorder API (MediaStream Recording) aims to provide a really simple mechanism by which developers can record media streams from the user's input devices and instantly use them in web apps, rather than having to perform manual encoding operations on raw PCM data, etc.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the experimental Web Platform features flag. Does not support audio recording, only video.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled using the Develop > Experimental Features menu.
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled using the Advanced > Experimental Features menu.

name: mediasource
title: Media Source Extensions
description: API allowing media data to be accessed from HTML `video` and `audio` elements.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE11 refers to only working in Windows 8+
notes_by_num.2: Fully supported only in iPadOS 13 and later.
notes_by_num.3: Due to compatibility issues, MediaSource Extensions are currently disabled by default in Samsung Internet.
notes_by_num.4: Fully supported only in iPadOS 13 and later.

name: menu
title: Context menu item (menuitem element)
description: Method of defining a context menu item, now deprecated and [removed from the HTML specification](https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/2730).

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to being limited to context menus, not toolbar menus.
notes_by_num.2: Nested menus are not supported

name: meta-theme-color
title: theme-color Meta Tag
description: Meta tag to define a suggested color that browsers should use to customize the display of the page or of the surrounding user interface. The meta tag overrides any theme-color set in the web app manifest.

notes_by_num.1: Desktop Chrome only uses the color on installed `progressive web apps`.
notes_by_num.2: Desktop Chrome 39-72 claimed to have support, but did not actually use the color anywhere. Chrome for Android did use the color in the toolbar.
notes_by_num.3: Chrome for Android does not use the color on devices with native `dark-mode` enabled.

name: meter
title: meter element
description: Method of indicating the current level of a gauge.

name: midi
title: Web MIDI API
description: The Web MIDI API specification defines a means for web developers to enumerate, manipulate and access MIDI devices

name: minmaxwh
title: CSS min/max-width/height
description: Method of setting a minimum or maximum width or height to an element.

notes_by_num.1: IE7 does not support `inherit` as a value on any of these properties.
notes_by_num.2: IE8 has some bugs with `max-width`/`height` combined with `overflow: auto`/`scroll`.

name: mp3
title: MP3 audio format
description: Popular lossy audio compression format

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older Firefox refers to being limited to certain operating systems.

name: mpeg-dash
title: Dynamic Adaptive Streaming over HTTP (MPEG-DASH)
description: HTTP-based media streaming communications protocol, an alternative to HTTP Live Streaming (HLS).

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `media.dash.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Only WebM video is supported.

name: mpeg4
title: MPEG-4/H.264 video format
description: Commonly used video compression format.

notes_by_num.1: The Android 2.3 browser requires [specific handling](https://www.broken-links.com/2010/07/08/making-html5-video-work-on-android-phones/) to play videos.
notes_by_num.2: Partial supports refers to the lack of hardware acceleration.

name: multibackgrounds
title: CSS3 Multiple backgrounds
description: Method of using multiple images as a background

name: multicolumn
title: CSS3 Multiple column layout
description: Method of flowing information in multiple columns

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not supporting the `break-before`, `break-after`, and `break-inside` properties. WebKit- and Blink-based browsers do have equivalent support for the non-standard `-webkit-column-break-*` properties to accomplish the same result (but only the `auto` and `always` values). Firefox does not support `break-*` but does support the now-obsolete `page-break-*` properties in the paging (printing) context.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting the `column-fill` property.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to not supporting the `avoid-column`, `column`, and `avoid` (in the column context) values for the properties `break-before`, `break-after`, and `break-inside`.

name: mutation-events
title: Mutation events
description: Deprecated mechanism for listening to changes made to the DOM, replaced by Mutation Observers.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `DOMAttrModified`
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `DOMNodeInsertedIntoDocument` & `DOMNodeRemovedFromDocument`

name: mutationobserver
title: Mutation Observer
description: Method for observing and reacting to changes to the DOM. Replaces MutationEvents, which is deprecated.

name: namevalue-storage
title: Web Storage - name/value pairs
description: Method of storing data locally like cookies, but for larger amounts of data (sessionStorage and localStorage, used to fall under HTML5).

name: native-filesystem-api
title: File System Access API
description: API for manipulating files in the device's local file system (not in a sandbox).

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in desktop Chromium browsers with the `#native-file-system-api` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Desktop Chromium browsers currently support basic functionality and will be adding more of the API in the future.

name: nav-timing
title: Navigation Timing API
description: API for accessing timing information related to navigation and elements.

name: netinfo
title: Network Information API
description: The Network Information API enables web applications to access information about the network connection in use by the device. Accessed via `navigator.connection`

notes_by_num.1: Supports only the `navigator.connection.type` value which doesn't match the latest spec. [see details](https://www.davidbcalhoun.com/2010/optimizing-based-on-connection-speed-using-navigator.connection-on-android-2.2-/)
notes_by_num.2: Only supports the `type` value.
notes_by_num.3: Only supports the `type` and `downlinkMax` values.
notes_by_num.4: Only supports the `downlink`, `effectiveType` & `rtt` values.

name: notifications
title: Web Notifications
description: Method of alerting the user outside of a web page by displaying notifications (that do not require interaction by the user).

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in `about:flags`
notes_by_num.2: Supports notifications via the [Push API](https://caniuse.com/#feat=push-api) but not the Web Notifications API.
notes_by_num.3: Chrome for Android requires the call to be made with a [service worker registration](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Notifications_API#Service_worker_additions)

name: object-entries
title: Object.entries
description: The `Object.entries()` method creates a multi-dimensional array of key value pairs from the given object.

name: object-fit
title: CSS3 object-fit/object-position
description: Method of specifying how an object (image or video) should fit inside its box. object-fit options include "contain" (fit according to aspect ratio), "fill" (stretches object to fill) and "cover" (overflows box but maintains ratio), where object-position allows the object to be repositioned like background-image does.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Safari refers to support for `object-fit` but not `object-position`.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Edge refers to `object-fit` only supporting `` ([see this comment](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/13603873/#comment-0))

name: object-observe
title: Object.observe data binding
description: Method for data binding, a now-withdrawn ECMAScript 7 proposal

name: object-values
title: Object.values method
description: The `Object.values()` method returns an array of a given object's own enumerable property values.

name: objectrtc
title: Object RTC (ORTC) API for WebRTC
description: Enables mobile endpoints to talk to servers and web browsers with Real-Time Communications (RTC) capabilities via native and simple JavaScript APIs

name: offline-apps
title: Offline web applications
description: Now deprecated method of defining web page files to be cached using a cache manifest file, allowing them to work offline on subsequent visits to the page.

name: offscreencanvas
title: OffscreenCanvas
description: OffscreenCanvas allows canvas drawing to occur with no connection to the DOM and can be used inside workers.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `gfx.offscreencanvas.enabled` flag. Currently only supports WebGL contexts, not 2D.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled via the `Experimental canvas features` flag

name: ogg-vorbis
title: Ogg Vorbis audio format
description: Vorbis is a free and open source audio format, most commonly used with the Ogg container.

name: ogv
title: Ogg/Theora video format
description: Free lossy video compression format.

name: ol-reversed
title: Reversed attribute of ordered lists
description: This attribute makes an ordered list number its items in descending order (large to small), instead of ascending order (small to large; the default). The order that the list items are displayed in is not affected.

name: once-event-listener
title: "once" event listener option
description: Causes an event listener to be automatically removed after it gets invoked, so that it only gets invoked once. Similar to jQuery's `$.one()` feature.

name: online-status
title: Online/offline status
description: Events to indicate when the user's connected (`online` and `offline` events) and the `navigator.onLine` property to see current status.

notes_by_num.0: Safari 7.0 supports only the event listener on `window`, and not on `document.body`
notes_by_num.1: Seems to support `navigator.onLine` but not `online`/`offline` events.
notes_by_num.2: IE8 only supports the `online`/`offline` events on `document.body`, rather than `window`.
notes_by_num.3: Desktop Firefox responds to the status of its "Work Offline" mode. If not in that mode, `navigator.onLine` is always `true`, regardless of the actual network connectivity status. [See bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=654579) for details.

name: opus
title: Opus
description: Royalty-free open audio codec by IETF, which incorporated SILK from Skype and CELT from Xiph.org, to serve higher sound quality and lower latency at the same bitrate.

notes_by_num.1: Supported only when packaged in a CAF file and on macOS High Sierra/iOS 11 or later.

name: orientation-sensor
title: Orientation Sensor
description: Defines a base orientation sensor interface and concrete sensor subclasses to monitor the deviceâ€™s physical orientation in relation to a stationary three dimensional Cartesian coordinate system.

notes_by_num.1: Available by enabling the "Generic Sensor" experimental flag in `about:flags`

name: outline
title: CSS outline properties
description: The CSS outline properties draw a border around an element that does not affect layout, making it ideal for highlighting. This covers the `outline` shorthand, as well as `outline-width`, `outline-style`, `outline-color` and `outline-offset`.

notes_by_num.1: Also supports the value of `invert` for `outline-color`. (support of this value is optional for browsers)
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `outline-offset`.

name: pad-start-end
title: String.prototype.padStart(), String.prototype.padEnd()
description: The `padStart()` and `padEnd()` methods pad the current string with a given string (eventually repeated) so that the resulting string reaches a given length. The pad is applied from the start (left) of the current string for `padStart()`, and applied from the end (right) of the current string for `padEnd()`.

name: page-transition-events
title: PageTransitionEvent
description: Fired at the Window when the page's entry in the session history stops being the current entry. Includes the `pageshow` and `pagehide` events.

name: pagevisibility
title: Page Visibility
description: JavaScript API for determining whether a document is visible on the display

name: passive-event-listener
title: Passive event listeners
description: Event listeners created with the `passive: true` option cannot cancel (`preventDefault()`) the events they receive. Primarily intended to be used with touch events and `wheel` events. Since they cannot prevent scrolls, passive event listeners allow the browser to perform optimizations that result in smoother scrolling.

name: path2d
title: Path2D
description: Allows path objects to be declared on 2D canvas surfaces

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the `addPath()` method

name: payment-request
title: Payment Request API
description: Payment Request is a new API for the open web that makes checkout flows easier, faster and consistent on shopping sites.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Payments API" flag
notes_by_num.3: Apple's proprietary implementation (see above)
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled via the "[Web Payments API](chrome://flags/#web-payments)" flag
notes_by_num.5: Unlike Desktop Chrome, support has been in Chrome for Android since version 53.
notes_by_num.6: Can be enabled via the `dom.payments.request.enabled` flag in "about:config" flag since 55.
notes_by_num.8: Disabled by default in Nightly. To enable, go to "about:config" and set "dom.payments.request.enabled" to true, and "dom.payments.request.supportedRegions" to "US,CA".

name: pdf-viewer
title: Built-in PDF viewer
description: Support for an PDF viewer that is part of the browser, rather than requiring a PDF file to be opened in an external application.

notes_by_num.1: Not supported in IE11 before Windows 10

name: permissions-api
title: Permissions API
description: High-level JavaScript API for checking and requesting permissions

name: permissions-policy
title: Permissions Policy
description: A security mechanism that allows developers to explicitly enable or disable various powerful browser features for a given site. Similar to [Document Policy](#feat=document-policy).

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Chromium browsers with the `enable-experimental-web-platform-features` flag.
notes_by_num.2: At least partially supports [Feature Policy](#feat=feature-policy), the predecessor to this spec.

name: picture
title: Picture element
description: A responsive images method to control which image resource a user agent presents to a user, based on resolution, media query and/or support for a particular image format

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Enabled in Opera through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in opera://flags
notes_by_num.3: Enabled in Firefox by setting the about:config preference dom.image.picture.enable to true

name: picture-in-picture
title: Picture-in-Picture
description: Allows websites to create a floating video window that is always on top of other windows so that users may continue consuming media while they interact with other sites or applications on their device.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to the fact that Mozilla provides an equivalent proprietary feature, which allows users to use Picture-in-Picture mode for all playing videos.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Firefox 71 refers to being enabled by default only for Windows users.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Firefox 68â€“70 refers to being enabled by default in Firefox pre-release channels for Windows users only.
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled in Firefox via the `media.videocontrols.picture-in-picture.enabled` pref in `about:config`.
notes_by_num.5: Can be enabled in Chrome via the `#enable-picture-in-picture` & `#enable-surfaces-for-videos` flags in `chrome://flags`.
notes_by_num.6: Partial support in Safari refers to the fact that Apple provides an equivalent proprietary API for Picture-in-Picture, which is only supported by macOS 10.12 Sierra & iOS 9 and newer.
notes_by_num.7: Partial support in Opera refers to the fact that Opera provides an equivalent proprietary feature named Video Pop Out, which allows users to use Picture-in-Picture mode for all playing videos.
notes_by_num.8: Automatically plays fullscreen videos in Picture-in-Picture mode after user hits Home Screen button. Only Android 8.0 Oreo and newer provide appropriate API for Picture-in-Picture.

name: ping
title: Ping attribute
description: When used on an anchor, this attribute signifies that the browser should send a ping request the resource the attribute points to.

notes_by_num.1: Disabled by default for [privacy reasons](http://kb.mozillazine.org/Browser.send_pings). Can be enabled via the `browser.send_pings` flag.

name: png-alpha
title: PNG alpha transparency
description: Semi-transparent areas in PNG files

name: pointer
title: Pointer events
description: This specification integrates various inputs from mice, touchscreens, and pens, making separate implementations no longer necessary and authoring for cross-device pointers easier. Not to be mistaken with the unrelated "pointer-events" CSS property.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE10 refers the lack of pointerenter and pointerleave events.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox support is disabled by default and [only supports mouse input](https://hacks.mozilla.org/2015/08/pointer-events-now-in-firefox-nightly/). On Windows only, touch can be enabled with the `layers.async-pan-zoom.enabled` and `dom.w3c_touch_events.enabled` flags
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled with the `#enable-pointer-events` flag.
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled under the `Experimental Features` menu.
notes_by_num.5: element.releasePointerCapture(pointerID) is only partially implemented. Calling it after pointerdown does not result in boundary events (pointerover pointerleave) being dispatched during pointer movements.
notes_by_num.6: Value of pointerevent.buttons is incorrect on pointermove events generated by touches. Is 0 but should be 1.

name: pointer-events
title: CSS pointer-events (for HTML)
description: This CSS property, when set to "none" allows elements to not receive hover/click events, instead the event will occur on anything behind it.

name: pointerlock
title: Pointer Lock API
description: API that provides access to raw mouse movement data. This is done by ignoring boundaries resulting from screen edges where the cursor can't go beyond, providing proper control for first person or real time strategy games.

name: portals
title: Portals
description: Portals enable seamless navigation between sites or pages. A new page can be loaded as an inset using the `<portal>` element (similar to an iframe) which can then seamlessly transition to the new navigated state when "activated".

notes_by_num.1: Available when registered for [origin trial](https://web.dev/hands-on-portals/#register-for-ot)
notes_by_num.2: Available by enabling the `#enable-portals` flag at `chrome://flags/`

name: prefers-color-scheme
title: prefers-color-scheme media query
description: Media query to detect if the user has set their system to use a light or dark color theme.

name: prefers-reduced-motion
title: prefers-reduced-motion media query
description: CSS media query based on a user preference for preferring reduced motion (animation, etc).

notes_by_num.1: Currently expected to land in Firefox for Windows and Linux in Firefox 63, for MacOS it might be delayed to Firefox 64.

name: progress
title: progress element
description: Method of indicating a progress state.

notes_by_num.1: iOS Safari does not support "indeterminate" <progress> elements.

name: promise-finally
title: Promise.prototype.finally
description: When the promise is settled, whether fulfilled or rejected, the specified callback function is executed.

name: promises
title: Promises
description: A promise represents the eventual result of an asynchronous operation.

name: proximity
title: Proximity API
description: Defines events that provide information about the distance between a device and an object, as measured by a proximity sensor.

name: proxy
title: Proxy object
description: The Proxy object allows custom behavior to be defined for fundamental operations. Useful for logging, profiling, object visualization, etc.

name: publickeypinning
title: Public Key Pinning
description: Declare that a website's HTTPS certificate should only be treated as valid if the public key is contained in a specified list to prevent MITM attacks that use valid CA-issued certificates.

name: push-api
title: Push API
description: API to allow messages to be pushed from a server to a browser, even when the site isn't focused or even open in the browser.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not supporting `PushEvent.data` and `PushMessageData`
notes_by_num.2: Requires full browser to be running to receive messages
notes_by_num.3: Safari supports a custom implementation https://developer.apple.com/notifications/safari-push-notifications/. WWDC video by apple : https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2013/614/
notes_by_num.4: Disabled on Firefox ESR, but can be re-enabled with the `dom.serviceWorkers.enabled` and `dom.push.enabled` flags

name: queryselector
title: querySelector/querySelectorAll
description: Method of accessing DOM elements using CSS selectors

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE8 is due to being limited to [CSS 2.1 selectors](/#feat=css-sel2) and a small subset of [CSS 3 selectors](/#feat=css-sel3) (see notes there). Additionally, it will have trouble with selectors including unrecognized tags (for example HTML5 ones).

name: readonly-attr
title: readonly attribute of input and textarea elements
description: Makes the form control non-editable. Unlike the `disabled` attribute, `readonly` form controls are still included in form submissions and the user can still select (but not edit) their value text.

notes_by_num.1: Readonly inputs of type `datetime-local`, `date`, `month`, and `week` can still be edited by pressing the Up or Down arrow keys on the keyboard while the input is focused.
notes_by_num.2: Text cannot be selected directly, but is possible by first selecting any text around the field.

name: referrer-policy
title: Referrer Policy
description: A policy that controls how much information is shared through the HTTP referrer header. Helps to protect user privacy.

notes_by_num.1: Browsers initially supported an [early draft](https://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Meta_referrer) of the specification which can only use a meta tag and is only compatible with the `origin` value from the new spec.
notes_by_num.2: Chrome 21-60 did not support the `same-origin`, `strict-origin` and `strict-origin-when-cross-origin` values. ([issue 627968](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=627968))
notes_by_num.3: Chrome is now defaulting to `strict-origin-when-cross-origin` which is the recommended setting for most use-cases.

name: registerprotocolhandler
title: Custom protocol handling
description: Method of allowing a webpage to handle a given protocol using `navigator.registerProtocolHandler`. This allows certain URLs to be opened by a given web application, for example `mailto:` addresses can be opened by a webmail client.

notes_by_num.1: Supports protocols `mailto`, `mms`, `nntp`, `rtsp`, and `webcal` but requires custom protocols to start with `web+`

name: rel-noopener
title: rel=noopener
description: Ensure new browsing contexts are opened without a useful `window.opener`

name: rel-noreferrer
title: Link type "noreferrer"
description: Links with `rel="noreferrer"` set do not send the request's "referrer" header. This prevents the destination site from seeing what URL the user came from.

notes_by_num.1: Only supported in IE11 in later versions of Windows 10 (creators update).

name: rellist
title: relList (DOMTokenList)
description: Method of easily manipulating rel attribute values on elements, using the DOMTokenList object (similar to classList).

notes_by_num.1: Support for relList on link but not anchor elements

name: rem
title: rem (root em) units
description: Type of unit similar to `em`, but relative only to the root element, not any parent element. Thus compounding does not occur as it does with `em` units.

notes_by_num.1: IE 9 & IE 10 do not support `rem` units when used in the `font` shorthand property (the entire declaration is ignored) or when used on pseudo elements.
notes_by_num.2: iOS Safari 5.0-5.1 support `rem` but not in combination with media queries.

name: requestanimationframe
title: requestAnimationFrame
description: API allowing a more efficient way of running script-based animation, compared to traditional methods using timeouts. Also covers support for `cancelAnimationFrame`

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to lacking `cancelAnimationFrame` support.
notes_by_num.2: Supports `webkitCancelRequestAnimationFrame` rather than `webkitCancelAnimationFrame`.

name: requestidlecallback
title: requestIdleCallback
description: API allowing the execution of JavaScript to be queued to run in idle browser time, either at the end of a frame or when the user is inactive. Also covers support for `cancelIdleCallback`. The API has similarities with `requestAnimationFrame`.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `dom.requestIdleCallback.enabled` flag
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled in Experimental (WebKit) Features

name: resizeobserver
title: Resize Observer
description: Method for observing and reacting to changes to sizes of DOM elements.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag

name: resource-timing
title: Resource Timing
description: Method to help web developers to collect complete timing information related to resources on a document.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the dom.enable_resource_timing flag
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari refers to being limited to OSX 10.12+

name: rest-parameters
title: Rest parameters
description: Allows representation of an indefinite number of arguments as an array.

notes_by_num.1: Requires the "Experimental JavaScript features" flag to be enabled

name: rtcpeerconnection
title: WebRTC Peer-to-peer connections
description: Method of allowing two users to communicate directly, browser to browser using the RTCPeerConnection API.

notes_by_num.1: BlackBerry 10 recognizes RTCPeerConnection but real support is unconfirmed.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled via the "Enable WebRTC 1.0" flag
notes_by_num.3: Edge does not support RTCDataChannel. See [API Catalogue](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/catalog/?q=specName%3Awebrtc)

name: ruby
title: Ruby annotation
description: Method of adding pronunciation or other annotations using ruby elements (primarily used in East Asian typography).

notes_by_num.1: IE9+ supports [properties](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Reference) of an older version of the CSS Ruby specification.

name: run-in
title: display: run-in
description: If the run-in box contains a block box, same as block. If a block box follows the run-in box, the run-in box becomes the first inline box of the block box. If an inline box follows, the run-in box becomes a block box.

notes_by_num.1: Not before inline-elements

name: same-site-cookie-attribute
title: 'SameSite' cookie attribute
description: Same-site cookies ("First-Party-Only" or "First-Party") allow servers to mitigate the risk of CSRF and information leakage attacks by asserting that a particular cookie should only be sent with requests initiated from the same registrable domain.
