notes_by_num.1: Not shipped with the inital release but later with the 2018 June security update (Patch Tuesday) to Windows 10 RS3 (2017 Fall Creators Update) and newer. [More info](https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/Status/issues/616).
notes_by_num.2: Partial support because only supported in IE 11 on Windows 10 RS3 (2017 Fall Creators Update) and newer, but not in IE 11 on other Windows versions (Windows 7, ...)
notes_by_num.3: Implemented [Incrementally Better Cookies](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-west-cookie-incrementalism-00) by default: Cookies without `SameSite` are treated as `Lax`, `SameSite=None` cookies without `Secure` are rejected.
notes_by_num.4: Partial due to the lack of support in macOS before 10.14 Mojave.
notes_by_num.5: Partial due to [the bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=198181) that treats `SameSite=None` and invalid values as `Strict` in macOS before 10.15 Catalina and in iOS before 13.

name: screen-orientation
title: Screen Orientation
description: Provides the ability to read the screen orientation state, to be informed when this state changes, and to be able to lock the screen orientation to a specific state.

notes_by_num.1: Not supported on Windows 7.

name: script-async
title: async attribute for external scripts
description: The boolean async attribute on script elements allows the external JavaScript file to run when it's available, without delaying page load first.

notes_by_num.1: Using script.async = false; to maintain execution order for dynamically-added scripts isn't supported in Safari 5.0

name: script-defer
title: defer attribute for external scripts
description: The boolean defer attribute on script elements allows the external JavaScript file to run when the DOM is loaded, without delaying page load first.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older IE refers to a buggy implementation (see issue).
notes_by_num.2: Deferred scripts may run after DOMContentLoaded - https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=688580

name: scrollintoview
title: scrollIntoView
description: The `Element.scrollIntoView()` method scrolls the current element into the visible area of the browser window. Parameters can be provided to set the position inside the visible area as well as whether scrolling should be instant or smooth.

notes_by_num.1: Supports scrollIntoView with boolean parameter, but not `smooth` behavior option

name: scrollintoviewifneeded
title: Element.scrollIntoViewIfNeeded()
description: If the element is fully within the visible area of the viewport, it does nothing. Otherwise, the element is scrolled into view. A proprietary variant of the standard `Element.scrollIntoView()` method.

name: sdch
title: SDCH Accept-Encoding/Content-Encoding
description: Shared Dictionary Compression over HTTP

name: selection-api
title: Selection API
description: API for accessing selected content of a document, including the `window.getSelection()` method, as well as the `selectstart` & `selectionchange` events on `document`.

notes_by_num.1: Supports `window.getSelection()` but no selection events
notes_by_num.2: Supports selection events, but not `window.getSelection()`
notes_by_num.3: Does not support the `selectstart` event
notes_by_num.4: `window.getSelection()` may fail on tapping buttons, as the selection is lost right before the listener code runs.
notes_by_num.5: Selection events are supported behind the `dom.select_events.enabled` flag

name: server-timing
title: Server Timing
description: Mechanism for web developers to annotate network requests with server timing information.

notes_by_num.1: Chrome v60-63: An older version of the API is behind the [Experimental Web Platform features](chrome://flags/#enable-experimental-web-platform-features) flag.
notes_by_num.2: Chrome v64: The current API is behind the [Experimental Web Platform features](chrome://flags/#enable-experimental-web-platform-features) flag.
notes_by_num.3: Safari v12.1+: Supports the Server Timing reporting in the Web Inspector Network tab, but not the JavaScript API

name: serviceworkers
title: Service Workers
description: Method that enables applications to take advantage of persistent background processing, including hooks to enable bootstrapping of web applications while offline.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support can be enabled in Firefox with the `dom.serviceWorkers.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Available behind the "Enable service workers" flag
notes_by_num.3: Disabled on Firefox ESR, but can be re-enabled with the `dom.serviceWorkers.enabled` flag
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu

name: setimmediate
title: Efficient Script Yielding: setImmediate()
description: Yields control flow without the minimum delays enforced by setTimeout

name: shadowdom
title: Shadow DOM (deprecated V0 spec)
description: Original V0 version of the Shadow DOM specification. See [Shadow DOM V1](#feat=shadowdomv1) for support for the latest version.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox behind the `dom.webcomponents.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Firefox behind the `dom.webcomponents.shadowdom.enabled` flag.

name: shadowdomv1
title: Shadow DOM (V1)
description: Method of establishing and maintaining functional boundaries between DOM trees and how these trees interact with each other within a document, thus enabling better functional encapsulation within the DOM & CSS.

notes_by_num.1: Certain CSS selectors do not work (`:host > .local-child`) and styling slotted content (`::slotted`) is buggy.
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the `dom.webcomponents.enabled` preference in `about:config`.
notes_by_num.3: Enabled through the `dom.webcomponents.shadowdom.enabled` preference in `about:config`.

name: sharedarraybuffer
title: Shared Array Buffer
description: Type of ArrayBuffer that can be shared across Workers.

notes_by_num.1: Has support, but was disabled across browsers in January 2018 due to Spectre & Meltdown vulnerabilities.
notes_by_num.2: Enabled by default in Nightly, but not in Beta/Developer/Release.
notes_by_num.3: Requires cross-origin isolation by having [Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy (COEP)](#feat=mdn-http_headers_cross-origin-embedder-policy) and [Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy (COOP)](#feat=mdn-http_headers_cross-origin-opener-policy) headers set. [Mozilla Hacks article](https://hacks.mozilla.org/2020/07/safely-reviving-shared-memory/) for context.

name: sharedworkers
title: Shared Web Workers
description: Method of allowing multiple scripts to communicate with a single web worker.

name: sni
title: Server Name Indication
description: An extension to the TLS computer networking protocol by which a client indicates which hostname it is attempting to connect to at the start of the handshaking process.

notes_by_num.1: Only supported on Windows Vista or above (not Windows XP)

name: spdy
title: SPDY protocol
description: Networking protocol for low-latency transport of content over the web. Superseded by HTTP version 2.

notes_by_num.1: Deprecated as of macOS Mojave 10.4.4. To be completely removed in a future version of macOS.
notes_by_num.2: Deprecated as of iOS 12.2. To be completely removed in a future version of iOS.

name: speech-recognition
title: Speech Recognition API
description: Method to provide speech input in a web browser.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to some attributes missing.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox currently has a `media.webspeech.recognition.enable` flag in about:config for this, but actual support is waiting for permissions to be sorted out.
notes_by_num.3: Reported to be in development for Samsung Internet for GearVR, due Q1/2017
notes_by_num.4: Edge and Opera appear to have support for the `SpeechRecognition` API but no events for it appear to fire.

name: speech-synthesis
title: Speech Synthesis API
description: A web API for controlling a text-to-speech output.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `media.webspeech.synth.enabled` about:config flag.
notes_by_num.2: Speech Synthesis in Chrome since version 55 stops playback after about 15 seconds on Windows 7 & 10, and Ubuntu 14.04, possibly other platforms

name: spellcheck-attribute
title: Spellcheck attribute
description: Attribute for `input`/`textarea` fields to enable/disable the browser's spellchecker.

name: sql-storage
title: Web SQL Database
description: Method of storing data client-side, allows SQLite database queries for access and manipulation

name: srcset
title: Srcset and sizes attributes
description: The `srcset` and `sizes` attributes on `img` (or `source`) elements allow authors to define various image resources and "hints" that assist a user agent to determine the most appropriate image source to display (e.g. high-resolution displays, small monitors, etc).

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox by setting the about:config preference dom.image.srcset.enabled to true
notes_by_num.2: Supports the subset of the syntax for resolution switching (using the `x` descriptor), but not the full syntax that can be used with `sizes` (using the `w` descriptor).
notes_by_num.3: Intermittently displays distorted images due to bug present (see known issues)

name: stream
title: getUserMedia/Stream API
description: Method of accessing external device data (such as a webcam video stream). Formerly this was envisioned as the <device> element.

notes_by_num.1: Blink-based (and some other) browsers support an older version of the spec that does not use `srcObject`. [See Chromium issue 387740](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=387740).
notes_by_num.2: Supports the older spec's `navigator.getUserMedia` API, not the newer `navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia` one.
notes_by_num.3: `getUserMedia` returns no video input devices in `UIWebView` or `WKWebView`, but only directly in Safari.
notes_by_num.4: Does not work in standalone running ("installed") PWAs.

name: streams
title: Streams
description: Method of creating, composing, and consuming streams of data, that map efficiently to low-level I/O primitives, and allow easy composition with built-in backpressure and queuing.

notes_by_num.1: IE implements a different API than the one from WHATWG.
notes_by_num.2: Only basic read support.
notes_by_num.3: Disabled by default behind the `javascript.options.streams` and `dom.streams.enabled` flags.
notes_by_num.4: No support for BYOB ("bring your own buffer") stream readers.
notes_by_num.5: No support for `WritableStream`.
notes_by_num.6: No support for the `pipeTo` or `pipeThrough` methods

name: stricttransportsecurity
title: Strict Transport Security
description: Declare that a website is only accessible over a secure connection (HTTPS).

notes_by_num.1: IE 11 added support [in an update](https://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2015/06/09/http-strict-transport-security-comes-to-internet-explorer-11-on-windows-8-1-and-windows-7/) on June 9, 2015

name: style-scoped
title: Scoped CSS
description: Allows CSS rules to be scoped to part of the document, based on the position of the style element. The attribute has been [removed from the current specification](https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/552).

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Enabled in Firefox through the about:config setting "layout.css.scoped-style.enabled"

name: subresource-integrity
title: Subresource Integrity
description: Subresource Integrity enables browsers to verify that file is delivered without unexpected manipulation.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu

name: svg
title: SVG (basic support)
description: Method of displaying basic Vector Graphics features using the embed or object elements. Refers to the SVG 1.1 spec.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Android 3 & 4 refers to not supporting masking.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE9-11 refers to not supporting animations.
notes_by_num.3: IE9-11 & Edge don't properly scale SVG files. [Adding height, width, viewBox, and CSS rules](https://codepen.io/tomByrer/pen/qEBbzw?editors=110) seems to be the best workaround.

name: svg-css
title: SVG in CSS backgrounds
description: Method of using SVG images as CSS backgrounds

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in iOS Safari and older Safari versions refers to failing to support tiling or the background-position property.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in older Firefox and Opera Mini/Mobile refers to SVG images being blurry when scaled.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Edge 15 and older refers to a lack of support for SVG data URIs. [see bug](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/6274479/)

name: svg-filters
title: SVG filters
description: Method of using Photoshop-like effects on SVG objects including blurring and color manipulation.

name: svg-fonts
title: SVG fonts
description: Method of using fonts defined as SVG shapes. Removed from [SVG 2.0](https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/changes.html#fonts) and considered as a deprecated feature with support being removed from browsers.

notes_by_num.1: Chrome 38 and newer support SVG fonts only on Windows Vista and XP.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Opera Mini in SVG images only, not in HTML.

name: svg-fragment
title: SVG fragment identifiers
description: Method of displaying only a part of an SVG image by defining a view ID or view box dimensions as the file's fragment identifier.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to support inside `` but not as CSS `background-image`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to lack of external fragments support

name: svg-html
title: SVG effects for HTML
description: Method of using SVG transforms, filters, etc on HTML elements using either CSS or the foreignObject element

notes_by_num.1: IE11 and below do not support `<foreignObject>`.
notes_by_num.2: IE and Edge do not support applying SVG filter effects to HTML elements using CSS. [Bug Report](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/6618695/)

name: svg-html5
title: Inline SVG in HTML5
description: Method of using SVG tags directly in HTML documents. Requires HTML5 parser.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support CSS transforms on SVG elements (transform attribute can be used instead)

name: svg-img
title: SVG in HTML img element
description: Method of displaying SVG images in HTML using .

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not supporting embedded images (data URIs) inside the SVG.

name: svg-smil
title: SVG SMIL animation
description: Method of using animation elements to animate SVG images

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older Safari versions refers to not working in HTML files or CSS background images.

name: sxg
title: Signed HTTP Exchanges (SXG)
description: Part of the Web Packaging spec, Signed HTTP Exchanges allow a different origin server to provide a resource, and this will be treated as if it came from the original server. This can be use with AMP CDNs, for example, to allow the original URL to be displayed in the URL bar.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support behind a feature flag (chrome://flags/#enable-signed-http-exchange)

name: tabindex-attr
title: tabindex global attribute
description: Specifies the focusability of the element and in what order (if any) it should become focused (relative to other elements) when "tabbing" through the document.

notes_by_num.1: On Mac OS X, unless Full Keyboard Access is enabled, `<a>` elements are not keyboard-focusable, even if they have `tabindex="0"`.
notes_by_num.2: `<a>` elements are never keyboard-focusable, even if they have `tabindex="0"`. Unless Full Keyboard Access is enabled, then `<button>`s, radio buttons, and checkboxes are also not keyboard-focusable, even if they have `tabindex="0"`.
notes_by_num.3: Has "previous" and "next" virtual keyboard buttons that follow tabindex order.

name: template
title: HTML templates
description: Method of declaring a portion of reusable markup that is parsed but not rendered until cloned.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support Document.importNode on templates, nested templates or elements that contain templates.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support Node.cloneNode on templates, nested templates or elements that contain templates.
notes_by_num.3: Safari 6.2 has the same partial support as Safari 7.1.

name: template-literals
title: ES6 Template Literals (Template Strings)
description: Template literals are string literals allowing embedded expressions. You can use multi-line strings and string interpolation features with them. Formerly known as template strings.

notes_by_num.1: Safari 12 [sometimes garbage collects](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=190756) the cached TemplateStrings used by Tagged Template Literals

name: text-decoration
title: text-decoration styling
description: Method of defining the type, style and color of lines in the text-decoration property. These can be defined as shorthand (e.g. `text-decoration: line-through dashed blue`) or as single properties (e.g. `text-decoration-color: blue`)

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting the `text-decoration-style` property.
notes_by_num.3: Safari 8+ supports `-webkit-text-decoration-skip` with values `none` and `skip` (other values behave like `none` or `skip`)
notes_by_num.4: Partial support refers to not supporting the `text-decoration-skip` property.
notes_by_num.5: Partial support refers to `text-decoration-skip` only supporting value `objects` and `ink`.

name: text-emphasis
title: text-emphasis styling
description: Method of using small symbols next to each glyph to emphasize a run of text, commonly used in East Asian languages. The `text-emphasis` shorthand, and its `text-emphasis-style` and `text-emphasis-color` longhands, can be used to apply marks to the text. The `text-emphasis-position` property, which inherits separately, allows setting the emphasis marks' position with respect to the text.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to incorrect support for `-webkit-text-emphasis-position`. These browsers support `over` and `under` as values, but not the added `left` and `right` values required by the spec.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `layout.css.text-emphasis.enabled` flag

name: text-overflow
title: CSS3 Text-overflow
description: Append ellipsis when text overflows its containing element

name: text-size-adjust
title: CSS text-size-adjust
description: On mobile devices, the text-size-adjust CSS property allows Web authors to control if and how the text-inflating algorithm is applied to the textual content of the element it is applied to.

notes_by_num.1: If the viewport size is set using a `<meta>` element, the `-ms-text-size-adjust` property is ignored. See [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/text-size-adjust)
notes_by_num.2: Old versions of WebKit-based desktop browsers (Chrome<27, Safari<6) [suffer from a bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=56543) where if `-webkit-text-size-adjust` is explicitly set to `none`, instead of ignoring the property, the browsers will prevent the user from zooming in or out on the webpage.

name: text-stroke
title: CSS text-stroke and text-fill
description: Method of declaring the outline (stroke) width and color for text.

notes_by_num.1: Firefox & Edge specifically only support the `-webkit-text-stroke` property (not using `-moz-` or `-ms-` prefix)
notes_by_num.2: Requires the `layout.css.prefixes.webkit` flag to be enabled.

name: textcontent
title: Node.textContent
description: DOM Node property representing the text content of a node and its descendants

name: textencoder
title: TextEncoder & TextDecoder
description: `TextEncoder` encodes a JavaScript string into bytes using the UTF-8 encoding and returns the resulting `Uint8Array` of those bytes. `TextDecoder` does the reverse.

notes_by_num.1: Not available in Web Workers in Firefox 19.

name: tls1-1
title: TLS 1.1
description: Version 1.1 of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol.

notes_by_num.1: Firefox 68+ displays a small warning icon in the address bar when connecting over TLS 1.1
notes_by_num.2: Firefox 78+ displays a full page dismissable warning the first time it connects over TLS 1.1
notes_by_num.3: Chrome 85+ and Safari for MacOS 13.1+ displays `Not secure` in the address bar when connecting over TLS 1.1
notes_by_num.4: Chrome 85+ displays a full page dismissable warning every time a new site connects over TLS 1.1

name: tls1-2
title: TLS 1.2
description: Version 1.2 of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol. Allows for data/message confidentiality, and message authentication codes for message integrity and as a by-product message authentication.

name: tls1-3
title: TLS 1.3
description: Version 1.3 (the latest one) of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol. Removes weaker elliptic curves and hash functions.

notes_by_num.1: Supports a draft of the TLS 1.3 specification, not the final version.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled in Firefox by setting the `security.tls.version.max` pref to "4" in `about:config`.
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled in Chrome and Opera via the `#tls13-variant` flag in `chrome://flags` or `opera://flags`.
notes_by_num.4: Partial support in Safari refers to being limited to macOS 10.14 Mojave and later.
notes_by_num.5: Partial support in Safari refers to being limited to macOS 10.14 Mojave and later.

name: touch
title: Touch events
description: Method of registering when, where and how the interface is touched, for devices with a touch screen. These DOM events are similar to mousedown, mousemove, etc.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the dom.w3c_touch_events.enabled flag (disabled by default for site compatibility reasons)
notes_by_num.2: Supported on IE11 Mobile for phones with "[Windows Phone 8.1 Update](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2014/07/31/the-mobile-web-should-just-work-for-everyone.aspx)"
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled in Edge using the "Enable touch events" flag under `about:flags`

name: transforms2d
title: CSS3 2D Transforms
description: Method of transforming an element including rotating, scaling, etc. Includes support for `transform` as well as `transform-origin` properties.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support CSS transforms on SVG elements (transform attribute can be used instead)

name: transforms3d
title: CSS3 3D Transforms
description: Method of transforming an element in the third dimension using the `transform` property. Includes support for the `perspective` property to set the perspective in z-space and the `backface-visibility` property to toggle display of the reverse side of a 3D-transformed element.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE refers to not supporting [the transform-style: preserve-3d property](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/hh673529%28v=vs.85%29.aspx#the_ms_transform_style_property). This prevents nesting 3D transformed elements.
notes_by_num.2: Safari 9 - 13 still require a prefix for the related `backface-visibility` property. [WebKit Bug 170983](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=170983) requests prefix removal.

name: trusted-types
title: Trusted Types for DOM manipulation
description: An API that forces developers to be very explicit about their use of powerful DOM-injection APIs. Can greatly improve security against XSS attacks.

name: ttf
title: TTF/OTF - TrueType and OpenType font support
description: Support for the TrueType (.ttf) and OpenType (.otf) outline font formats in @font-face.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE9+ refers to the fonts only working [when set to be "installable"](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/07/15/the-css-corner-better-web-typography-for-better-design.aspx). Support for this is tracked [here](https://status.modern.ie/crossdomainfontloading).

name: typedarrays
title: Typed Arrays
description: JavaScript typed arrays provide a mechanism for accessing raw binary data much more efficiently. Includes: `Int8Array`, `Uint8Array`, `Uint8ClampedArray`, `Int16Array`, `Uint16Array`, `Int32Array`, `Uint32Array`, `Float32Array` & `Float64Array`

notes_by_num.1: IE10 (and IE 10&11 mobile) does not support `Uint8ClampedArray`

name: u2f
title: FIDO U2F API
description: JavaScript API to interact with Universal Second Factor (U2F) devices. This allows users to log into sites more securely using two-factor authentication with a USB dongle.

notes_by_num.1: Requires the "FIDO U2F (Universal 2nd Factor)" Chrome extension
notes_by_num.2: Support can be enabled with the "security.webauth.u2f" flag
notes_by_num.3: Supported [via the internal CryptoTokenExtension.](https://github.com/google/u2f-ref-code/blob/master/u2f-gae-demo/war/js/u2f-api.js)

name: unhandledrejection
title: unhandledrejection/rejectionhandled events
description: The `unhandledrejection` event is fired when a Promise is rejected but there is no rejection handler to deal with the rejection. The `rejectionhandled` event is fired when a Promise is rejected, and after the rejection is handled by the promise's rejection handling code.

name: upgradeinsecurerequests
title: Upgrade Insecure Requests
description: Declare that browsers should transparently upgrade HTTP resources on a website to HTTPS.

name: url
title: URL API
description: API to retrieve the various parts that make up a given URL from a given URL string.

notes_by_num.1: Allows objects to be created via `URL` constructor, but instances do not have the expected url properties.

name: url-scroll-to-text-fragment
title: URL Scroll-To-Text Fragment
description: URL fragment that defines a piece of text to be scrolled into view and highlighted.

name: urlsearchparams
title: URLSearchParams
description: The URLSearchParams interface defines utility methods to work with the query string of a URL.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only supporting `entries()`, `keys()`, `values()`, and `for...of`.

name: use-strict
title: ECMAScript 5 Strict Mode
description: Method of placing code in a "strict" operating context.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older Safari refers to strict mode still accepting a lot of JS that should be considered invalid.

name: user-select-none
title: CSS user-select: none
description: Method of preventing text/element selection using CSS.

name: user-timing
title: User Timing API
description: Method to help web developers measure the performance of their applications by giving them access to high precision timestamps.

name: variable-fonts
title: Variable fonts
description: OpenType font settings that allows a single font file to behave like multiple fonts: it can contain all the allowed variations in width, weight, slant, optical size, or any other exposed axes of variation as defined by the font designer. Variations can be applied via the `font-variation-settings` property.

notes_by_num.1: Works with Experimental Web Platform features enabled
notes_by_num.2:
Requires MacOS 10.12+ and the following about:config flags to be enabled:
`layout.css.font-variations.enabled`,
`gfx.downloadable_fonts.keep_variation_tables`
notes_by_num.3: Requires MacOS 10.13+
notes_by_num.4: Does not support the `font-weight` and `font-stretch` properties.
notes_by_num.5: Does not support `format('truetype-variations')`, `format('woff-variations')`, `format('woff2-variations')`
notes_by_num.6: Does not support OpenType-CFF2 fonts

name: vibration
title: Vibration API
description: Method to access the vibration mechanism of the hosting device.

name: video
title: Video element
description: Method of playing videos on webpages (without requiring a plug-in). Includes support for the following media properties: `currentSrc`, `currentTime`, `paused`, `playbackRate`, `buffered`, `duration`, `played`, `seekable`, `ended`, `autoplay`, `loop`, `controls`, `volume` & `muted`

notes_by_num.1: The Android browser (before 2.3) requires [specific handling](http://www.broken-links.com/2010/07/08/making-html5-video-work-on-android-phones/) to run the video element.
notes_by_num.2: Old Firefox versions were missing support for some properties: `loop` was added in v11, `played` in v15, `playbackRate` in v20.
notes_by_num.3: Ignores the `autoplay` attribute by default, though autoplay behavior can be [enabled by users](https://webkit.org/blog/7734/auto-play-policy-changes-for-macos/)

name: videotracks
title: Video Tracks
description: Method of specifying and selecting between multiple video tracks. Useful for providing sign language tracks, burnt-in captions or subtitles, alternative camera angles, etc.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox by enabling "media.track.enabled" in about:config
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Chrome and Opera by enabling "enable-experimental-web-platform-features" in chrome:flags

name: viewport-units
title: Viewport units: vw, vh, vmin, vmax
description: Length units representing a percentage of the current viewport dimensions: width (vw), height (vh), the smaller of the two (vmin), or the larger of the two (vmax).

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE9 refers to supporting "vm" instead of "vmin".
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting the "vmax" unit.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in iOS7 is due to buggy behavior of the "vh" unit (see workarounds: [1](https://gist.github.com/pburtchaell/e702f441ba9b3f76f587), [2](https://gist.github.com/BenMorel/e9e34c08360ebbbd0634)).

name: wai-aria
title: WAI-ARIA Accessibility features
description: Method of providing ways for people with disabilities to use dynamic web content and web applications.

name: wake-lock
title: Screen Wake Lock API
description: API to prevent devices from dimming, locking or turning off the screen when the application needs to keep running.

notes_by_num.1: Available behind the #experimental-web-platform-features feature flag

name: wasm
title: WebAssembly
description: WebAssembly or "wasm" is a new portable, size- and load-time-efficient format suitable for compilation to the web.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `javascript.options.wasm` in `about:config`
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled via the `#enable-webassembly` flag
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled via the Experimental JavaScript Features flag
notes_by_num.4: Disabled for Firefox 52 ESR
notes_by_num.5: Available in Samsung Internet 7 beta

name: wav
title: Wav audio format
description: Waveform Audio File Format, aka WAV or WAVE, a typically uncompressed audio format.

name: wbr-element
title: wbr (word break opportunity) element
description: Represents an extra place where a line of text may optionally be broken.

name: web-animation
title: Web Animations API
description: Lets you create animations that are run in the browser, as well as inspect and manipulate animations created through declarative means like CSS.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to basic support of `element.animate()`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to basic support of `element.animate()` and [playback control of AnimationPlayer](https://www.chromestatus.com/features/5633748733263872)
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Firefox is detailed in [Are we animated yet?](https://birtles.github.io/areweanimatedyet/)
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu
notes_by_num.5: Does not support [composite modes](https://drafts.csswg.org/web-animations-1/#effect-composition)

name: web-app-manifest
title: Add to home screen (A2HS)
description: The ability for a user to "install" a website and use it as if it was a natively installed app. To enable this behaviour, a website must serve a valid Web App Manifest and load it's assets through a [Service Worker](https://caniuse.com/#feat=serviceworkers).

notes_by_num.1: A manifest could be used to list apps in the Microsoft Store, which would use Edge as a back-end.
notes_by_num.2: Safari on iOS does not support A2HS in WebViews like Chrome and Firefox.
notes_by_num.3: Firefox is experimenting with desktop support behind the `browser.ssb.enabled` flag.

name: web-bluetooth
title: Web Bluetooth
description: Allows web sites to communicate over GATT with nearby user-selected Bluetooth devices in a secure and privacy-preserving way.

notes_by_num.1: Available by enabling the "Web Bluetooth" experimental flag in `about:flags`. Currently support [varies by OS](https://github.com/WebBluetoothCG/web-bluetooth/blob/gh-pages/implementation-status.md)
notes_by_num.2: Only in Opera Mobile
notes_by_num.3: Available in [Origin Trials](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/07/interact-with-ble-devices-on-the-web#available-for-origin-trials) for Chrome OS, Android M, and Mac
notes_by_num.4: Currently support [varies by OS](https://github.com/WebBluetoothCG/web-bluetooth/blob/gh-pages/implementation-status.md)

name: web-share
title: Web Share API
description: A way to allow websites to invoke the native sharing capabilities of the host platform

notes_by_num.1: Implemented old [Web Intents](https://dvcs.w3.org/hg/web-intents/raw-file/tip/spec/Overview-respec.html)
notes_by_num.2: [Android intent:// URLs](https://developer.chrome.com/multidevice/android/intents) can be used instead.
notes_by_num.3: Only supported on Windows
notes_by_num.4: support is only for Windows.
notes_by_num.5: Did not support share click that would trigger a [fetch call](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=197779).

name: webauthn
title: Web Authentication API
description: The Web Authentication API is an extension of the Credential Management API that enables strong authentication with public key cryptography, enabling password-less authentication and / or secure second-factor authentication without SMS texts.

notes_by_num.1:
Can be enabled at `about:flags`

Edge 13 used an earlier draft syntax. As of Edge 14 the implementation is prefixed and based on the FIDO 2.0 Web APIs.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled using the Develop > Experimental Features menu. Currently supports USB-based CTAP & CTAP2 HID devices.
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled in Settings under the Safari > Advanced > Experimental Features menu.
notes_by_num.4: Partial support refers to FIDO2 devices not working if a PIN is set.
notes_by_num.5: Experimental feature not yet enabled in WKWebView-based browsers including Chrome for iOS.

name: webgl
title: WebGL - 3D Canvas graphics
description: Method of generating dynamic 3D graphics using JavaScript, accelerated through hardware

notes_by_num.1: WebGL context is accessed from "experimental-webgl" rather than "webgl"

name: webgl2
title: WebGL 2.0
description: Next version of WebGL. Based on OpenGL ES 3.0.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox by setting the about:config preference webgl.enable-prototype-webgl2 to true
notes_by_num.2: WebGL2 context is accessed from "experimental-webgl2" rather than "webgl2"
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled in Chrome by passing the "--enable-unsafe-es3-apis" flag when starting the browser through the command line
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled in the "Experimental Features" developer menu
notes_by_num.5: Enabled by default for Nightly and Dev Edition

name: webgpu
title: WebGPU
description: An API for complex rendering and compute, using hardware acceleration. Use cases include demanding 3D games and acceleration of scientific calculations. Meant to supersede WebGL.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox with the `dom.webgpu.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled in Safari on MacOS with the `WebGPU` experimental feature.
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled in some Chromium browsers on Windows and MacOS with the `enable-unsafe-webgpu` flag.

name: webhid
title: WebHID API
description: Enables raw access to HID (Human Interface Device) commands for all connected HIDs. Previously, an HID could only be accessed if the browser had implemented a custom API for the specific device.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled with the #enable-experimental-web-platform-features flag
notes_by_num.2: Available via [origin trial](https://developers.chrome.com/origintrials/#/view_trial/1074108511127863297)

name: webm
title: WebM video format
description: Multimedia format designed to provide a royalty-free, high-quality open video compression format for use with HTML5 video. WebM supports the video codec VP8 and VP9.

notes_by_num.1: Older browser versions did not support all codecs.
notes_by_num.2: Older Edge versions did not support progressive sources.
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled in Internet Explorer and Safari for MacOS by manually installing the codecs in the operating system.
notes_by_num.4: Safari only supports [VP8 used in WebRTC](https://webkit.org/blog/8672/on-the-road-to-webrtc-1-0-including-vp8/).
notes_by_num.5: Safari only supports [VP8 used in WebRTC](https://webkit.org/blog/8672/on-the-road-to-webrtc-1-0-including-vp8/) and [VP9 used in WebRTC](https://webkit.org/blog/10929/release-notes-for-safari-technology-preview-110/).

name: webnfc
title: Web NFC
description: This API allows a website to communicate with NFC tags through a device's NFC reader.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Chromium browsers behind the `enable-experimental-web-platform-features` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Current implementations only allow communication through the NDEF protocol in order to minimize security and privacy issues.

name: webp
title: WebP image format
description: Image format (based on the VP8 video format) that supports lossy and lossless compression, as well as animation and alpha transparency. WebP generally has better compression than JPEG, PNG and GIF and is designed to supersede them. [AVIF](#feat=avif) is designed to supersede WebP.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not supporting lossless, alpha and animated WebP images.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting animated WebP images.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Safari refers to being limited to macOS 11 Big Sur and later.

name: websockets
title: Web Sockets
description: Bidirectional communication technology for web apps

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older browsers refers to the websockets implementation using an older version of the protocol and/or the implementation being disabled by default (due to security issues with the older protocol).
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in older browsers refers to lacking support for binary data.

name: webusb
title: WebUSB
description: Allows communication with devices via USB (Universal Serial Bus).

name: webvr
title: WebVR API
description: API for accessing virtual reality (VR) devices, including sensors and head-mounted displays. Replaced by the WebXR Device API.

notes_by_num.1: Available and enabled by default only in Firefox Windows. Enabled in Nightly for iOS. Firefox 73+ [requires a secure context using HTTPS](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebVR_API#API_availability)
notes_by_num.2: [Was in development](https://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2016/09/09/webvr-in-development-edge/#3lMW05DTZXbXcK46.97) in the latest Edge builds and supported only [Windows Mixed Reality](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/mixed-reality).
notes_by_num.3: Supports only Samsung Galaxy devices with the Samsung Gear VR

name: webvtt
title: WebVTT - Web Video Text Tracks
description: Format for marking up text captions for multimedia resources.

notes_by_num.1: Firefox currently lacks support for the `::cue` pseudo-element. [See bug #865395.](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=865395)

name: webworkers
title: Web Workers
description: Method of running scripts in the background, isolated from the web page

name: webxr
title: WebXR Device API
description: API for accessing virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) devices, including sensors and head-mounted displays.

notes_by_num.1: This API is very extensive. Many of its features are still in development and/or don't have finalised specs yet.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled in Firefox behind the `dom.vr.webxr.enabled` flag.

name: will-change
title: CSS will-change property
description: Method of optimizing animations by informing the browser which elements will change and what properties will change.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox behind the `layout.css.will-change.enabled` flag

name: woff
title: WOFF - Web Open Font Format
description: Compressed TrueType/OpenType font that contains information about the font's source.

notes_by_num.1: Reported to be supported in some modified versions of the Android 4.0 browser.

name: woff2
title: WOFF 2.0 - Web Open Font Format
description: TrueType/OpenType font that provides better compression than WOFF 1.0.

notes_by_num.1: Supported only on Safari for Mac OS Sierra, not El Capitan & older.

name: word-break
title: CSS3 word-break
description: Property to prevent or allow words to be broken over multiple lines between letters.

name: wordwrap
title: CSS3 Overflow-wrap
description: Allows lines to be broken within words if an otherwise unbreakable string is too long to fit. Currently mostly supported using the `word-wrap` property.

name: x-doc-messaging
title: Cross-document messaging
description: Method of sending information from a page on one domain to a page on a different one (using postMessage)

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only working in frames/iframes (not other tabs/windows). Also, objects cannot be sent using postMessage.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to [limitations in certain conditions](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/16226924/is-cross-origin-postmessage-broken-in-ie10).

name: x-frame-options
title: X-Frame-Options HTTP header
description: An HTTP header which indicates whether the browser should allow the webpage to be displayed in a frame within another webpage. Used as a defense against clickjacking attacks.

name: xhr2
title: XMLHttpRequest advanced features
description: Adds more functionality to XHR (aka AJAX) requests like file uploads, transfer progress information and the ability to send form data. Previously known as [XMLHttpRequest Level 2](https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/WD-XMLHttpRequest-20120117/), these features now appear simply in the XMLHttpRequest spec.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not supporting `json` as `responseType`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting `.timeout` and `.ontimeout`
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to not supporting `blob` as `responseType`

name: xhtml
title: XHTML served as application/xhtml+xml
description: A strict form of HTML, and allows embedding of other XML languages

name: xhtmlsmil
title: XHTML+SMIL animation
description: Method of using SMIL animation in web pages

name: xml-serializer
title: DOM Parsing and Serialization
description: Various DOM parsing and serializing functions, specifically `DOMParser`, `XMLSerializer`, `innerHTML`, `outerHTML` and `insertAdjacentHTML`.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to lacking support for `parseFromString` on the DOMParser.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to supporting only `innerHTML`.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to supporting only `innerHTML` and `insertAdjacentHTML`.
